text: This paper focuses on subword-based Neural Machine Translation (NMT). We hypothesize that in the NMT model, the appropriate subword units for the following three modules (layers) can differ: (1) the encoder embedding layer, (2) the decoder embedding layer, and (3) the decoder output layer. We find the subword based on Sennrich et al. (2016) has a feature that a large vocabulary is a superset of a small vocabulary and modify the NMT model enables the incorporation of several different subword units in a single embedding layer. We refer these small subword features as hierarchical subword features. To empirically investigate our assumption, we compare the performance of several different subword units and hierarchical subword features for both the encoder and decoder embedding layers. We confirmed that incorporating hierarchical subword features in the encoder consistently improves BLEU scores on the IWSLT evaluation datasets.

text: This paper delves into the topic of subword-based Neural Machine Translation (NMT). Our hypothesis is that the appropriate subword units for the following three modules (layers) in the NMT model can vary: (1) the encoder embedding layer, (2) the decoder embedding layer, and (3) the decoder output layer. We adopt the subword approach proposed by Sennrich et al. (2016), which has the advantage of a large vocabulary being a superset of a smaller vocabulary. This enables us to modify the NMT model to incorporate multiple subword units in a single embedding layer, referred to as hierarchical subword features. To validate our hypothesis, we compare the performance of various subword units and hierarchical subword features for both the encoder and decoder embedding layers. Our results show that incorporating hierarchical subword features in the encoder consistently improves BLEU scores on the IWSLT evaluation datasets.

text: Building query graphs from natural language questions is an important step in complex question answering over knowledge graph (Complex KGQA). In general, a question can be correctly answered if its query graph is built correctly and the right answer is then retrieved by issuing the query graph against the KG. Therefore, this paper focuses on query graph generation from natural language questions. Existing approaches for query graph generation ignore the semantic structure of a question, resulting in a large number of noisy query graph candidates that undermine prediction accuracies. In this paper, we define six semantic structures from common questions in KGQA and develop a novel Structure-BERT to predict the semantic structure of a question. By doing so, we can first filter out noisy candidate query graphs by the predicted semantic structures, and then rank the remaining candidates with a BERT-based ranking model. Extensive experiments on two popular benchmarks MetaQA and WebQuestionsSP (WSP) demonstrate the effectiveness of our method as compared to state-of-the-arts.

label: coling
text: Building query graphs from natural language questions is a crucial step in Complex Knowledge Graph Question Answering (Complex KGQA). The correct answer to a question can be obtained if its query graph is correctly constructed and the query graph is executed against the knowledge graph. This paper focuses on the generation of query graphs from natural language questions. Currently, existing methods for query graph generation do not consider the semantic structure of questions, leading to a large number of noisy query graph candidates that negatively impact prediction accuracy. To address this issue, we define six semantic structures from common questions in KGQA and introduce a novel Structure-BERT model to predict the semantic structure of a question. This allows us to filter out noisy candidates by predicting the semantic structure and rank the remaining candidates using a BERT-based ranking model. Our method is evaluated on two popular benchmarks, MetaQA and WebQuestionsSP (WSP), and demonstrates superior performance compared to the state-of-the-art.

text: A core part of linguistic typology is the classification of languages according to linguistic properties, such as those detailed in the World Atlas of Language Structure (WALS). Doing this manually is prohibitively time-consuming, which is in part evidenced by the fact that only 100 out of over 7,000 languages spoken in the world are fully covered in WALS. We learn distributed language representations, which can be used to predict typological properties on a massively multilingual scale. Additionally, quantitative and qualitative analyses of these language embeddings can tell us how language similarities are encoded in NLP models for tasks at different typological levels. The representations are learned in an unsupervised manner alongside tasks at three typological levels: phonology (grapheme-to-phoneme prediction, and phoneme reconstruction), morphology (morphological inflection), and syntax (part-of-speech tagging). We consider more than 800 languages and find significant differences in the language representations encoded, depending on the target task. For instance, although Norwegian Bokmål and Danish are typologically close to one another, they are phonologically distant, which is reflected in their language embeddings growing relatively distant in a phonological task. We are also able to predict typological features in WALS with high accuracies, even for unseen language families.

text: The core of linguistic typology involves classifying languages based on linguistic properties, such as those outlined in the World Atlas of Language Structure (WALS). To overcome this, we use distributed language representations to predict typological properties on a massive multilingual scale. These representations are learned through unsupervised methods while performing tasks at three typological levels: phonology (grapheme-to-phoneme prediction and phoneme reconstruction), morphology (morphological inflection), and syntax (part-of-speech tagging). Our analysis of these language embeddings reveals significant differences in their encoding, depending on the target task. For instance, while Norwegian Bokmål and Danish are typologically similar, they are phonologically distinct, which is reflected in their language embeddings becoming relatively distant during a phonological task. Additionally, we are able to predict typological features in WALS with high accuracy, even for language families that have not been seen before.

text: In supervised learning of morphological patterns, the strategy of generalizing inflectional tables into more abstract paradigms through alignment of the longest common subsequence found in an inflection table has been proposed as an efficient method to deduce the inflectional behavior of unseen word forms. In this paper, we extend this notion of morphological `paradigm' from earlier work and provide a formalization that more accurately matches linguist intuitions about what an inflectional paradigm is. Additionally, we propose and evaluate a mechanism for learning full human-readable paradigm specifications from incomplete data—a scenario when we only have access to a few inflected forms for each lexeme, and want to reconstruct the missing inflections as well as generalize and group the witnessed patterns into a model of more abstract paradigmatic behavior of lexemes.

text: The strategy of generalizing inflectional tables into more abstract paradigms by aligning the longest common subsequence found in an inflection table has been proposed as an efficient method for deducing the inflectional behavior of unseen word forms in supervised learning of morphological patterns. This paper extends the notion of a morphological `paradigm' from previous work and provides a more accurate formalization that matches linguistic intuition. Additionally, we propose and evaluate a mechanism for learning full, human-readable paradigm specifications from incomplete data. This scenario occurs when we only have access to a few inflected forms for each lexeme and aim to reconstruct the missing inflections, as well as generalize and group the observed patterns into a model of more abstract paradigmatic behavior for lexemes.

text: This paper focuses on the most basic implicational universals in phonological theory, called T-orders after Anttila and Andrus (2006). It shows that the T-orders predicted by stochastic (and partial order) Optimality Theory coincide with those predicted by categorical OT. Analogously, the T-orders predicted by stochastic Harmonic Grammar coincide with those predicted by categorical HG. In other words, these stochastic constraint-based frameworks do not tamper with the typological structure induced by the original categorical frameworks.

label: emnlp
text: This paper examines the fundamental implicational universals in phonological theory, referred to as T-orders, as described by Anttila and Andrus (2006). The study demonstrates that the T-orders predicted by stochastic Optimality Theory (OT) and partial order OT align with those predicted by categorical OT. Similarly, the T-orders predicted by stochastic Harmonic Grammar (HG) are consistent with those predicted by categorical HG. In essence, these stochastic constraint-based frameworks do not alter the typological structure established by the original categorical frameworks.

text: With the recent advancements in deep learning, neural solvers have gained promising results in solving math word problems. However, these SOTA solvers only generate binary expression trees that contain basic arithmetic operators and do not explicitly use the math formulas. As a result, the expression trees they produce are lengthy and uninterpretable because they need to use multiple operators and constants to represent one single formula. In this paper, we propose sequence-to-general tree (S2G) that learns to generate interpretable and executable operation trees where the nodes can be formulas with an arbitrary number of arguments. With nodes now allowed to be formulas, S2G can learn to incorporate mathematical domain knowledge into problem-solving, making the results more interpretable. Experiments show that S2G can achieve a better performance against strong baselines on problems that require domain knowledge.

text: With recent advancements in deep learning, neural solvers have shown promising results in solving math word problems. However, current state-of-the-art (SOTA) solvers only generate binary expression trees that contain basic arithmetic operators and do not explicitly use math formulas. This results in lengthy, uninterpretable expression trees that require multiple operators and constants to represent a single formula. In this paper, we propose the sequence-to-General tree (S2G) approach, which learns to generate interpretable and executable operation trees in which nodes can be formulas with an arbitrary number of arguments. By allowing nodes to be formulas, S2G can incorporate mathematical domain knowledge into problem-solving, making the results more interpretable. Experiments show that S2G outperforms strong baselines on problems that require domain knowledge.

text: Though existing researches have achieved impressive results in controlled text generation, they focus mainly on single-attribute control. However, in applications like automatic comments, the topic and sentiment need to be controlled simultaneously. In this work, we propose a new framework for multi-attribute controlled text generation. To achieve this, we design a contrastive-generator that can effectively generate texts with more attributes. In order to increase the convergence of the text on the desired attributes, we adopt an external-discriminator to distinguish whether the generated text holds the desired attributes. Moreover, we propose top-n weighted decoding to further improve the relevance of texts to attributes. Automated evaluations and human evaluations show that our framework achieves remarkable controllability in multi-attribute generation while keeping the text fluent and diverse. It also yields promising performance on zero-shot generation.

label: coling
text: Existing research in controlled text generation has made impressive progress, but it primarily focuses on single-attribute control. However, in applications such as automatic comments, it is necessary to control both the topic and sentiment simultaneously. Our proposed framework addresses this challenge by introducing a contrastive-generator that can effectively generate text with multiple attributes. To improve the convergence of the text towards the desired attributes, we use an external-discriminator to verify that the generated text holds the desired attributes. Additionally, we employ top-n weighted decoding to further enhance the relevance of the text to the attributes. Both automated evaluations and human evaluations demonstrate that our framework effectively balances multi-attribute control with fluency and diversity in the generated text, and it performs well in zero-shot generation.

label: naacl
text: Information about the meaning of mathematical variables in text is useful in NLP/IR tasks such as symbol disambiguation, topic modeling and mathematical information retrieval (MIR). We introduce variable typing, the task of assigning one mathematical type (multi-word technical terms referring to mathematical concepts) to each variable in a sentence of mathematical text. As part of this work, we also introduce a new annotated data set composed of 33,524 data points extracted from scientific documents published on arXiv. Our intrinsic evaluation demonstrates that our data set is sufficient to successfully train and evaluate current classifiers from three different model architectures. The best performing model is evaluated on an extrinsic task: MIR, by producing a typed formula index. Our results show that the best performing MIR models make use of our typed index, compared to a formula index only containing raw symbols, thereby demonstrating the usefulness of variable typing.

label: naacl
text: We present the task of variable typing, which involves assigning mathematical types to variables in mathematical text for NLP/IR tasks such as symbol disambiguation, topic modeling, and mathematical information retrieval (MIR). To support this task, we have created a new annotated data set with 33,524 data points extracted from scientific documents on arXiv. Our intrinsic evaluation indicates that the data set is suitable for training and evaluating classifiers from three different model architectures. The best-performing model is then evaluated on an extrinsic task, MIR, by constructing a typed formula index. Our results demonstrate that the best-performing MIR models benefit from using our typed index, as compared to a formula index containing only raw symbols, highlighting the significance of variable typing.

label: emnlp
text: The text in many web documents is organized into a hierarchy of section titles and corresponding prose content, a structure which provides potentially exploitable information on discourse structure and topicality. However, this organization is generally discarded during text collection, and collecting it is not straightforward: the same visual organization can be implemented in a myriad of different ways in the underlying HTML. To remedy this, we present a flexible system for automatically extracting the hierarchical section titles and prose organization of web documents irrespective of differences in HTML representation. This system uses features from syntax, semantics, discourse and markup to build two models which classify HTML text into section titles and prose text. When tested on three different domains of web text, our domain-independent system achieves an overall precision of 0.82 and a recall of 0.98. The domain-dependent variation produces very high precision (0.99) at the expense of recall (0.75). These results exhibit a robust level of accuracy suitable for enhancing question answering, information extraction, and summarization.

label: emnlp
text: Many web documents have text organized into a hierarchy of section titles and corresponding prose content, providing valuable information on discourse structure and topicality. However, this organization is often lost during text collection and collecting it can be challenging as the same visual organization can be implemented in various ways in the HTML code. To address this issue, we present a flexible system for automatically extracting the hierarchical section titles and prose organization of web documents, regardless of differences in HTML representation. Our system uses features from syntax, semantics, discourse, and markup to build two models that classify HTML text into section titles and prose text. When tested on three different domains of web text, our domain-independent system achieved an overall precision of 0.82 and a recall of 0.98. The domain-dependent variation produced very high precision (0.99) at the cost of recall (0.75). These results demonstrate a high level of accuracy, making our system suitable for enhancing question answering, information extraction, and summarization.

label: acl
text: Document-level text simplification often deletes some sentences besides performing lexical, grammatical or structural simplification to reduce text complexity. In this work, we focus on sentence deletions for text simplification and use a news genre-specific functional discourse structure, which categorizes sentences based on their contents and their function roles in telling a news story, for predicting sentence deletion. We incorporate sentence categories into a neural net model in two ways for predicting sentence deletions, either as additional features or by jointly predicting sentence deletions and sentence categories. Experimental results using human-annotated data show that incorporating the functional structure improves the recall of sentence deletion prediction by 6.5% and 10.7% respectively using the two methods, and improves the overall F1-score by 3.6% and 4.3% respectively.

label: acl
text: Document-level text simplification often involves the deletion of certain sentences, in addition to performing lexical, grammatical, or structural simplification to reduce text complexity. In this study, we concentrate on sentence deletions for text simplification and use a news genre-specific functional discourse structure to predict sentence deletion. This structure categorizes sentences based on their content and function in telling a news story. We incorporate these sentence categories into a neural net model in two ways: as additional features or by jointly predicting sentence deletions and sentence categories. Our experimental results, using human-annotated data, indicate that incorporating the functional structure improves the recall of sentence deletion prediction by 6.5% and 10.7% for the two methods, respectively, and enhances the overall F1-score by 3.6% and 4.3% respectively.

label: coling
text: Automatically evaluating the coherence of summaries is of great significance both to enable cost-efficient summarizer evaluation and as a tool for improving coherence by selecting high-scoring candidate summaries. While many different approaches have been suggested to model summary coherence, they are often evaluated using disparate datasets and metrics. This makes it difficult to understand their relative performance and identify ways forward towards better summary coherence modelling. In this work, we conduct a large-scale investigation of various methods for summary coherence modelling on an even playing field. Additionally, we introduce two novel analysis measures, _intra-system correlation_ and _bias matrices_, that help identify biases in coherence measures and provide robustness against system-level confounders. While none of the currently available automatic coherence measures are able to assign reliable coherence scores to system summaries across all evaluation metrics, large-scale language models fine-tuned on self-supervised tasks show promising results, as long as fine-tuning takes into account that they need to generalize across different summary lengths.

label: coling
text: The significance of automatically evaluating the coherence of summaries cannot be overstated. It not only enables cost-effective summarizer evaluation but also serves as a tool for improving coherence by selecting high-scoring candidate summaries. However, the various methods for modeling summary coherence have often been evaluated using disparate datasets and metrics, making it challenging to understand their relative performance and identify ways to improve coherence modeling. To address this issue, we conduct a comprehensive investigation of various coherence modeling methods on an even playing field. Furthermore, we introduce two novel analysis measures, intra-system correlation and bias matrices, that help identify biases in coherence measures and provide robustness against system-level confounding factors. Although currently available automatic coherence measures are not able to provide reliable coherence scores for system summaries across all evaluation metrics, fine-tuning large-scale language models on self-supervised tasks shows promising results, as long as the fine-tuning process takes into account the need to generalize across different summary lengths.

label: acl
text: Text-level discourse rhetorical structure (DRS) parsing is known to be challenging due to the notorious lack of training data. Although recent top-down DRS parsers can better leverage global document context and have achieved certain success, the performance is still far from perfect. To our knowledge, all previous DRS parsers make local decisions for either bottom-up node composition or top-down split point ranking at each time step, and largely ignore DRS parsing from the global view point. Obviously, it is not sufficient to build an entire DRS tree only through these local decisions. In this work, we present our insight on evaluating the pros and cons of the entire DRS tree for global optimization. Specifically, based on recent well-performing top-down frameworks, we introduce a novel method to transform both gold standard and predicted constituency trees into tree diagrams with two color channels. After that, we learn an adversarial bot between gold and fake tree diagrams to estimate the generated DRS trees from a global perspective. We perform experiments on both RST-DT and CDTB corpora and use the original Parseval for performance evaluation. The experimental results show that our parser can substantially improve the performance when compared with previous state-of-the-art parsers.

label: acl
text: Parsing text-level discourse rhetorical structure (DRS) is a challenging task due to the limited amount of available training data. Although recent top-down DRS parsers have achieved some success by leveraging global document context, their performance is still far from perfect. Previous DRS parsers make local decisions for either bottom-up node composition or top-down split point ranking, ignoring the global view. Building an entire DRS tree through these local decisions alone is insufficient. In this work, we present a novel method to evaluate the entire DRS tree for global optimization. Our method transforms both gold standard and predicted constituency trees into two-color tree diagrams and learns an adversarial bot between them to estimate the generated DRS trees globally. Our experiments on the RST-DT and CDTB corpora, evaluated using the original Parseval, show that our parser significantly improves performance compared to previous state-of-the-art parsers.

label: naacl
text: Homographs, words with different meanings but the same surface form, have long caused difficulty for machine translation systems, as it is difficult to select the correct translation based on the context. However, with the advent of neural machine translation (NMT) systems, which can theoretically take into account global sentential context, one may hypothesize that this problem has been alleviated. In this paper, we first provide empirical evidence that existing NMT systems in fact still have significant problems in properly translating ambiguous words. We then proceed to describe methods, inspired by the word sense disambiguation literature, that model the context of the input word with context-aware word embeddings that help to differentiate the word sense before feeding it into the encoder. Experiments on three language pairs demonstrate that such models improve the performance of NMT systems both in terms of BLEU score and in the accuracy of translating homographs.

label: naacl
text: The use of homographs, words with the same surface form but different meanings, has long posed challenges for machine translation systems. It can be difficult to select the correct translation based on context. However, with the advent of neural machine translation (NMT) systems, it was thought that this issue would be addressed as these systems are designed to take into account global sentential context. In this paper, we provide evidence that existing NMT systems still struggle to accurately translate ambiguous words. To address this issue, we propose methods inspired by word sense disambiguation literature that model the context of the input word using context-aware word embeddings. This helps to differentiate the word sense before it is fed into the encoder. Our experiments on three language pairs show that these models improve the performance of NMT systems, both in terms of BLEU score and the accuracy of translating homographs.

label: acl
text: We present Knowledge Enhanced Multimodal BART (KM-BART), which is a Transformer-based sequence-to-sequence model capable of reasoning about commonsense knowledge from multimodal inputs of images and texts. We adapt the generative BART architecture (Lewis et al., 2020) to a multimodal model with visual and textual inputs. We further develop novel pretraining tasks to improve the model performance on the Visual Commonsense Generation (VCG) task. In particular, our pretraining task of Knowledge-based Commonsense Generation (KCG) boosts model performance on the VCG task by leveraging commonsense knowledge from a large language model pretrained on external commonsense knowledge graphs. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to propose a dedicated task for improving model performance on the VCG task. Experimental results show that our model reaches state-of-the-art performance on the VCG task (Park et al., 2020) by applying these novel pretraining tasks.

label: acl
text: We present Knowledge Enhanced Multimodal BART (KM-BART), a Transformer-based sequence-to-sequence model that can reason about commonsense knowledge from multimodal inputs of images and texts. Our model adapts the generative BART architecture (Lewis et al., 2020) to incorporate both visual and textual inputs. To further improve its performance on the Visual Commonsense Generation (VCG) task, we introduce novel pretraining tasks, specifically the Knowledge-based Commonsense Generation (KCG) task. This task leverages commonsense knowledge from a large language model pretrained on external commonsense knowledge graphs, resulting in a significant boost in performance on the VCG task. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time a dedicated task has been proposed to improve performance on the VCG task. Our experiments demonstrate that KM-BART reaches state-of-the-art performance on the VCG task (Park et al., 2020) through the use of these innovative pretraining tasks.

label: acl
text: Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) aims to identify the correct meaning of polysemous words in the particular context. Lexical resources like WordNet which are proved to be of great help for WSD in the knowledge-based methods. However, previous neural networks for WSD always rely on massive labeled data (context), ignoring lexical resources like glosses (sense definitions). In this paper, we integrate the context and glosses of the target word into a unified framework in order to make full use of both labeled data and lexical knowledge. Therefore, we propose GAS: a gloss-augmented WSD neural network which jointly encodes the context and glosses of the target word. GAS models the semantic relationship between the context and the gloss in an improved memory network framework, which breaks the barriers of the previous supervised methods and knowledge-based methods. We further extend the original gloss of word sense via its semantic relations in WordNet to enrich the gloss information. The experimental results show that our model outperforms the state-of-the-art systems on several English all-words WSD datasets.

label: acl
text: The goal of Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) is to determine the correct meaning of polysemous words in a specific context. To achieve this, lexical resources such as WordNet have been found to be useful in knowledge-based methods. However, previous neural network-based WSD methods have only relied on large amounts of labeled data, ignoring lexical resources such as glosses (sense definitions). In this study, we present GAS, a gloss-augmented WSD neural network that combines the context and glosses of the target word to take full advantage of both labeled data and lexical knowledge. Our model uses an improved memory network framework to encode the semantic relationship between the context and gloss, breaking down the limitations of previous supervised and knowledge-based methods. Additionally, we have enhanced the original gloss of the word sense by incorporating semantic relations found in WordNet. Our experiments demonstrate that GAS outperforms state-of-the-art systems on several English all-words WSD datasets.

label: acl
text: South Asia is home to a plethora of languages, many of which severely lack access to new language technologies. This linguistic diversity also results in a research environment conducive to the study of comparative, contact, and historical linguistics–fields which necessitate the gathering of extensive data from many languages. We claim that data scatteredness (rather than scarcity) is the primary obstacle in the development of South Asian language technology, and suggest that the study of language history is uniquely aligned with surmounting this obstacle. We review recent developments in and at the intersection of South Asian NLP and historical-comparative linguistics, describing our and others' current efforts in this area. We also offer new strategies towards breaking the data barrier.

label: acl
text: South Asia is a hub of linguistic diversity, with numerous languages that lack access to modern language technologies. This rich linguistic environment creates opportunities for the study of comparative, contact, and historical linguistics, which require the collection of vast data from multiple languages. The primary challenge in developing language technology in South Asia is not a lack of data, but rather its scatteredness. To overcome this obstacle, we propose that the study of language history can play a crucial role. In this paper, we review recent advancements in South Asian Natural Language Processing (NLP) and historical-comparative linguistics, highlighting our and others' efforts in this field. Additionally, we offer new approaches to breaking the data barrier.

label: naacl
text: Deep learning has been the mainstream technique in the natural language processing (NLP) area. However, deep learning requires many labeled data and is less generalizable across domains. Meta-learning is an arising field in machine learning. It studies approaches to learning better learning algorithms and aims to improve algorithms in various aspects, including data efficiency and generalizability. The efficacy of meta-learning has been shown in many NLP tasks, but there is no systematic survey of these approaches in NLP, which hinders more researchers from joining the field. Our goal with this survey paper is to offer researchers pointers to relevant meta-learning works in NLP and attract more attention from the NLP community to drive future innovation. This paper first introduces the general concepts of meta-learning and the common approaches. Then we summarize task construction settings, applications of meta-learning for various NLP problems and review the development of meta-learning in the NLP community.

label: naacl
text: Deep learning has been the leading technique in the field of natural language processing (NLP). However, it requires a large amount of labeled data and is not always generalizable across domains. Meta-learning, a rising field in machine learning, studies ways to improve learning algorithms and aims to enhance their data efficiency and generalizability. Despite its demonstrated efficacy in NLP tasks, there is a lack of systematic surveys of meta-learning approaches in NLP, hindering wider adoption. This survey paper aims to provide researchers with a comprehensive overview of relevant meta-learning works in NLP, and to attract more attention from the NLP community to drive future innovation. This paper covers the general concepts of meta-learning and its common approaches, summarizes task construction settings, and reviews the application of meta-learning to various NLP problems. Additionally, it provides an overview of the development of meta-learning in the NLP community.

label: naacl
text: Current approaches for controlling dialogue response generation are primarily focused on high-level attributes like style, sentiment, or topic. In this work, we focus on constrained long-term dialogue generation, which involves more fine-grained control and requires a given set of control words to appear in generated responses. This setting requires a model to not only consider the generation of these control words in the immediate context, but also produce utterances that will encourage the generation of the words at some time in the (possibly distant) future. We define the problem of constrained long-term control for dialogue generation, identify gaps in current methods for evaluation, and propose new metrics that better measure long-term control. We also propose a retrieval-augmented method that improves performance of long-term controlled generation via logit modification techniques. We show through experiments on three task-oriented dialogue datasets that our metrics better assess dialogue control relative to current alternatives and that our method outperforms state-of-the-art constrained generation baselines.

label: naacl
text: The current methods for controlling dialogue response generation are centered on high-level attributes such as style, sentiment, or topic. In this study, we concentrate on the constrained long-term dialogue generation that demands a more nuanced control and the presence of specified control words in the generated responses. The model must not only take into account the generation of these control words in the current context but also produce utterances that will facilitate the generation of these words at some point in the future. We identify the limitations of current evaluation methods and propose new metrics to better measure long-term control. Additionally, we introduce a retrieval-augmented method that enhances the performance of long-term controlled generation through logit modification techniques. Our experiments on three task-oriented dialogue datasets demonstrate that our metrics provide a more accurate assessment of dialogue control compared to current alternatives and that our method outperforms the state-of-the-art constrained generation baselines.

label: coling
text: Traditional training paradigms for extractive and abstractive summarization systems always only use token-level or sentence-level training objectives. However, the output summary is always evaluated from summary-level which leads to the inconsistency in training and evaluation. In this paper, we propose a Contrastive Learning based re-ranking framework for one-stage summarization called CoLo. By modeling a contrastive objective, we show that the summarization model is able to directly generate summaries according to the summary-level score without additional modules and parameters. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CoLo boosts the extractive and abstractive results of one-stage systems on CNN/DailyMail benchmark to 44.58 and 46.33 ROUGE-1 score while preserving the parameter efficiency and inference efficiency. Compared with state-of-the-art multi-stage systems, we save more than 100 GPU training hours and obtaining 3x 8x speed-up ratio during inference while maintaining comparable results.

label: coling
text: Traditional training paradigms for extractive and abstractive summarization systems only use token-level or sentence-level training objectives. However, the output summaries are always evaluated at the summary-level, leading to an inconsistency between training and evaluation. To address this issue, we propose CoLo, a Contrastive Learning-based re-ranking framework for one-stage summarization. By incorporating a contrastive objective, our model generates summaries directly based on summary-level scores, without the need for additional modules or parameters. Our experiments show that CoLo significantly improves the results of one-stage systems on the CNN/DailyMail benchmark, achieving 44.58 and 46.33 ROUGE-1 scores for extractive and abstractive summarization, respectively. Additionally, compared to state-of-the-art multi-stage systems, CoLo requires significantly less GPU training time and is 3-8 times faster during inference, while still producing comparable results.

label: coling
text: Neural machine translation (NMT) systems are usually trained on a large amount of bilingual sentence pairs and translate one sentence at a time, ignoring inter-sentence information. This may make the translation of a sentence ambiguous or even inconsistent with the translations of neighboring sentences. In order to handle this issue, we propose an inter-sentence gate model that uses the same encoder to encode two adjacent sentences and controls the amount of information flowing from the preceding sentence to the translation of the current sentence with an inter-sentence gate. In this way, our proposed model can capture the connection between sentences and fuse recency from neighboring sentences into neural machine translation. On several NIST Chinese-English translation tasks, our experiments demonstrate that the proposed inter-sentence gate model achieves substantial improvements over the baseline.

label: coling
text: Neural machine translation (NMT) systems are typically trained on a large corpus of bilingual sentence pairs and translate one sentence at a time, ignoring inter-sentence information. This can lead to ambiguity or inconsistencies in the translation of a sentence, particularly when compared to neighboring sentences. To address this issue, we propose an inter-sentence gate model that uses a shared encoder to encode two adjacent sentences and regulates the flow of information from the preceding sentence to the current sentence with an inter-sentence gate. This allows our model to capture the relationship between sentences and incorporate recency from neighboring sentences into NMT. Our experiments on several NIST Chinese-English translation tasks show that the proposed inter-sentence gate model significantly improves performance over the baseline.

label: emnlp
text: Current lexical simplification approaches rely heavily on heuristics and corpus level features that do not always align with human judgment. We create a human-rated word-complexity lexicon of 15,000 English words and propose a novel neural readability ranking model with a Gaussian-based feature vectorization layer that utilizes these human ratings to measure the complexity of any given word or phrase. Our model performs better than the state-of-the-art systems for different lexical simplification tasks and evaluation datasets. Additionally, we also produce SimplePPDB++, a lexical resource of over 10 million simplifying paraphrase rules, by applying our model to the Paraphrase Database (PPDB).

text: Current lexical simplification methods are heavily dependent on heuristics and corpus-level features that do not always match human perceptions. We have developed a 15,000-word English language lexicon rated for word complexity by humans and a novel neural readability ranking model. This model uses these human ratings to determine the complexity of words or phrases and features a Gaussian-based feature vectorization layer. Our model outperforms state-of-the-art systems in various lexical simplification tasks and evaluation datasets. Additionally, we have created SimplePPDB++, a lexical resource containing over 10 million simplifying paraphrase rules, by applying our model to the Paraphrase Database (PPDB).

text: Opinion summarization is the task of automatically generating summaries that encapsulate information expressed in multiple user reviews. We present Semantic Autoencoder (SemAE) to perform extractive opinion summarization in an unsupervised manner. SemAE uses dictionary learning to implicitly capture semantic information from the review text and learns a latent representation of each sentence over semantic units. Our extractive summarization algorithm leverages the representations to identify representative opinions among hundreds of reviews. SemAE is also able to perform controllable summarization to generate aspect-specific summaries using only a few samples. We report strong performance on SPACE and AMAZON datasets and perform experiments to investigate the functioning of our model.

label: acl
text: Opinion summarization is the process of creating summaries from multiple user reviews to encapsulate their information. To perform extractive opinion summarization in an unsupervised manner, we introduce the Semantic Autoencoder (SemAE). This model uses dictionary learning to capture semantic information from the review text and learns a latent representation of each sentence based on semantic units. Our extractive summarization algorithm uses these representations to identify the most representative opinions from hundreds of reviews. Additionally, SemAE can generate aspect-specific summaries through controllable summarization using only a few samples. Our experiments on the SPACE and AMAZON datasets show strong performance and provide insight into how our model operates.

text: The existing research efforts in Multimodal Sentiment Analysis (MSA) have focused on developing the expressive ability of neural networks to fuse information from different modalities. However, these approaches lack a mechanism to understand the complex relations within and across different modalities, since some sentiments may be scattered in different modalities. To this end, in this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical graph contrastive learning (HGraph-CL) framework for MSA, aiming to explore the intricate relations of intra- and inter-modal representations for sentiment extraction. Specifically, regarding the intra-modal level, we build a unimodal graph for each modality representation to account for the modality-specific sentiment implications. Based on it, a graph contrastive learning strategy is adopted to explore the potential relations based on unimodal graph augmentations. Furthermore, we construct a multimodal graph of each instance based on the unimodal graphs to grasp the sentiment relations between different modalities. Then, in light of the multimodal augmentation graphs, a graph contrastive learning strategy over the inter-modal level is proposed to ulteriorly seek the possible graph structures for precisely learning sentiment relations. This essentially allows the framework to understand the appropriate graph structures for learning intricate relations among different modalities. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets show that the proposed framework outperforms the state-of-the-art baselines in MSA.

text: The current research in Multimodal Sentiment Analysis (MSA) has been focused on improving the ability of neural networks to combine information from different modes. However, these methods lack a mechanism to comprehend the complex relationships between and across different modalities as some sentiments may be dispersed across different modes. To address this issue, we present a novel framework, the Hierarchical Graph Contrastive Learning (HGraph-CL) for MSA. Our framework aims to explore the intricate relationships of intra- and inter-modal representations for sentiment extraction. For the intra-modal level, we develop a unimodal graph for each modality representation to capture the specific sentiment implications. A graph contrastive learning strategy is then employed to explore the potential relationships based on unimodal graph augmentations. At the inter-modal level, we construct a multimodal graph for each instance based on the unimodal graphs to grasp the sentiment relationships between different modalities. Finally, a graph contrastive learning strategy is proposed over the inter-modal level to seek the appropriate graph structures for precisely learning sentiment relationships. Our framework enables a better understanding of the intricate relationships among different modalities, as demonstrated by the experimental results on two benchmark datasets, where it outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in MSA.

text: Linguists distinguish between novel and conventional metaphor, a distinction which the metaphor detection task in NLP does not take into account. Instead, metaphoricity is formulated as a property of a token in a sentence, regardless of metaphor type. In this paper, we investigate the limitations of treating conventional metaphors in this way, and advocate for an alternative which we name `metaphorical polysemy detection' (MPD). In MPD, only conventional metaphoricity is treated, and it is formulated as a property of word senses in a lexicon. We develop the first MPD model, which learns to identify conventional metaphors in the English WordNet. To train it, we present a novel training procedure that combines metaphor detection with `word sense disambiguation' (WSD). For evaluation, we manually annotate metaphor in two subsets of WordNet. Our model significantly outperforms a strong baseline based on a state-of-the-art metaphor detection model, attaining an ROC-AUC score of .78 (compared to .65) on one of the sets. Additionally, when paired with a WSD model, our approach outperforms a state-of-the-art metaphor detection model at identifying conventional metaphors in text (.659 F1 compared to .626).

text: Linguists distinguish the difference between novel and conventional metaphors. However, the metaphor detection task in NLP does not take this distinction into account. Instead, it considers metaphoricity as a property of a token in a sentence, regardless of the type of metaphor. In this paper, we examine the limitations of this approach and propose an alternative called `Metaphorical Polysemy Detection' (MPD). MPD only considers conventional metaphoricity and defines it as a property of word senses in a lexicon. We present the first MPD model that identifies conventional metaphors in English WordNet using a novel training procedure that combines metaphor detection with word sense disambiguation. We evaluate the model by manually annotating two subsets of WordNet and compare it to a strong baseline based on a state-of-the-art metaphor detection model. The results show that our model outperforms the baseline, achieving an ROC-AUC score of .78 compared to .65 on one of the sets. Additionally, when paired with a WSD model, our approach outperforms the state-of-the-art metaphor detection model in identifying conventional metaphors in text, with a .659 F1 score compared to .626.

text: Recent work has found that multi-task training with a large number of diverse tasks can uniformly improve downstream performance on unseen target tasks. In contrast, literature on task transferability has established that the choice of intermediate tasks can heavily affect downstream task performance. In this work, we aim to disentangle the effect of scale and relatedness of tasks in multi-task representation learning. We find that, on average, increasing the scale of multi-task learning, in terms of the number of tasks, indeed results in better learned representations than smaller multi-task setups. However, if the target tasks are known ahead of time, then training on a smaller set of related tasks is competitive to the large-scale multi-task training at a reduced computational cost.

label: naacl
text: Recent studies have revealed that multi-task training with a significant number of diverse tasks can enhance overall performance on unseen target tasks. However, research on task transferability has shown that the selection of intermediate tasks can significantly impact downstream performance. In this study, we aim to separate the impact of the scale and relatedness of tasks in multi-task representation learning. Our findings indicate that, on average, increasing the scale of multi-task learning, in terms of the number of tasks, leads to improved representation learning compared to smaller multi-task setups. However, when the target tasks are known in advance, training on a smaller set of related tasks can be just as effective as large-scale multi-task training, while also reducing computational costs.

text: Existing temporal relation (TempRel) annotation schemes often have low inter-annotator agreements (IAA) even between experts, suggesting that the current annotation task needs a better definition. This paper proposes a new multi-axis modeling to better capture the temporal structure of events. In addition, we identify that event end-points are a major source of confusion in annotation, so we also propose to annotate TempRels based on start-points only. A pilot expert annotation effort using the proposed scheme shows significant improvement in IAA from the conventional 60's to 80's (Cohen's Kappa). This better-defined annotation scheme further enables the use of crowdsourcing to alleviate the labor intensity for each annotator. We hope that this work can foster more interesting studies towards event understanding.

text: Current temporal relation (TempRel) annotation schemes frequently exhibit low inter-annotator agreements (IAA), even among experts, which suggests that the current annotation method requires improvement. This paper proposes a new multi-axis modeling approach to capture the temporal structure of events more effectively. Furthermore, we have found that event end-points are a significant source of confusion in the annotation process, so we suggest annotating TempRels based solely on start-points. A pilot expert annotation effort utilizing our proposed scheme resulted in a significant improvement in IAA, from 60's to 80's (Cohen's Kappa). This improved annotation method also enables the use of crowdsourcing to reduce the workload for each annotator, thereby fostering further research into event understanding.

text: Emotion category is usually divided into different ones by human beings, but it is indeed difficult to clearly distinguish and define the boundaries between different emotion categories. The existing studies working on emotion detection usually focus on how to improve the performance of model prediction, in which emotions are represented with one-hot vectors. However, emotion relations are ignored in one-hot representations. In this article, we first propose a general framework to learn the distributed representations for emotion categories in emotion space from a given emotion classification dataset. Furthermore, based on the soft labels predicted by the pre-trained neural network model, we derive a simple and effective algorithm. Experiments have validated that the proposed representations in emotion space can express emotion relations much better than word vectors in semantic space.

text: The categorization of emotions into different categories is a common practice among humans, but it can be challenging to accurately distinguish and define the boundaries between these categories. Existing studies in emotion detection tend to focus on improving the performance of model predictions, represented by one-hot vectors. However, these one-hot representations overlook the relationships between emotions. In this article, we introduce a framework for learning distributed representations of emotion categories in an emotion space, using a given emotion classification dataset. Our proposed method, based on the soft labels generated by a pre-trained neural network model, is both simple and effective. Our experiments show that our proposed representations in the emotion space better express emotion relationships compared to word vectors in semantic space.

text: Recent years have witnessed a surge of publications aimed at tracing temporal changes in lexical semantics using distributional methods, particularly prediction-based word embedding models. However, this vein of research lacks the cohesion, common terminology and shared practices of more established areas of natural language processing. In this paper, we survey the current state of academic research related to diachronic word embeddings and semantic shifts detection. We start with discussing the notion of semantic shifts, and then continue with an overview of the existing methods for tracing such time-related shifts with word embedding models. We propose several axes along which these methods can be compared, and outline the main challenges before this emerging subfield of NLP, as well as prospects and possible applications.

text: Recent years have seen a significant increase in the number of publications focused on tracing changes in lexical semantics over time using distributional methods, particularly prediction-based word embedding models. Despite this growth, the field lacks coherence, a common terminology, and shared practices compared to more established areas of natural language processing. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of academic research in the area of diachronic word embeddings and semantic shift detection. We begin by defining semantic shifts and then provide an overview of the existing methods for tracing these time-related changes using word embedding models. We outline the main challenges facing this emerging subfield of NLP, propose several axes for comparing these methods, and discuss the potential applications and future prospects of this research.

text: Distributional word representations (often referred to as word embeddings) are omnipresent in modern NLP. Early work has focused on building representations for word types, and recent studies show that lemmatization and part of speech (POS) disambiguation of targets in isolation improve the performance of word embeddings on a range of downstream tasks. However, the reasons behind these improvements, the qualitative effects of these operations and the combined performance of lemmatized and POS disambiguated targets are less studied. This work aims to close this gap and puts previous findings into a general perspective. We examine the effect of lemmatization and POS typing on word embedding performance in a novel resource-based evaluation scenario, as well as on standard similarity benchmarks. We show that these two operations have complimentary qualitative and vocabulary-level effects and are best used in combination. We find that the improvement is more pronounced for verbs and show how lemmatization and POS typing implicitly target some of the verb-specific issues. We claim that the observed improvement is a result of better conceptual alignment between word embeddings and lexical resources, stressing the need for conceptually plausible modeling of word embedding targets.

text: The use of distributional word representations, known as word embeddings, is widespread in modern NLP. Early research focused on building representations for individual word types, but recent studies have shown that lemmatization and part of speech (POS) disambiguation of targets in isolation can improve the performance of word embeddings in various downstream tasks. However, the reasons behind these improvements, the qualitative effects of these operations, and the combined performance of lemmatized and POS disambiguated targets have not been thoroughly studied. This work aims to fill this gap by putting previous findings into a general perspective. We evaluate the impact of lemmatization and POS typing on word embedding performance in a novel resource-based evaluation scenario and standard similarity benchmarks. Our findings show that these two operations have complementary qualitative and vocabulary-level effects and are most effective when used in combination. The improvement is particularly pronounced for verbs, which highlights the need for better alignment between word embeddings and lexical resources. This study emphasizes the importance of conceptually plausible modeling of word embedding targets.

text: Triangular machine translation is a special case of low-resource machine translation where the language pair of interest has limited parallel data, but both languages have abundant parallel data with a pivot language. Naturally, the key to triangular machine translation is the successful exploitation of such auxiliary data. In this work, we propose a transfer-learning-based approach that utilizes all types of auxiliary data. As we train auxiliary source-pivot and pivot-target translation models, we initialize some parameters of the pivot side with a pre-trained language model and freeze them to encourage both translation models to work in the same pivot language space, so that they can be smoothly transferred to the source-target translation model. Experiments show that our approach can outperform previous ones.

text: Triangular machine translation deals with a special case of low-resource translation where the language pair of interest has limited parallel data, but both languages have an abundance of parallel data with a pivot language. The success of triangular machine translation relies on effectively utilizing this auxiliary data. We propose a transfer-learning-based approach that incorporates all types of auxiliary data. To encourage the auxiliary source-pivot and pivot-target translation models to work in the same pivot language space, we initialize some parameters of the pivot side with a pre-trained language model and freeze them. Our experiments demonstrate that our approach outperforms previous ones.

label: acl
text: Few-shot Named Entity Recognition (NER) exploits only a handful of annotations to iden- tify and classify named entity mentions. Pro- totypical network shows superior performance on few-shot NER. However, existing prototyp- ical methods fail to differentiate rich seman- tics in other-class words, which will aggravate overfitting under few shot scenario. To address the issue, we propose a novel model, Mining Undefined Classes from Other-class (MUCO), that can automatically induce different unde- fined classes from the other class to improve few-shot NER. With these extra-labeled unde- fined classes, our method will improve the dis- criminative ability of NER classifier and en- hance the understanding of predefined classes with stand-by semantic knowledge. Experi- mental results demonstrate that our model out- performs five state-of-the-art models in both 1- shot and 5-shots settings on four NER bench- marks. We will release the code upon accep- tance. The source code is released on https: //github.com/shuaiwa16/OtherClassNER.git.

text: Few-shot Named Entity Recognition (NER) uses only a small number of annotations to identify and classify named entity mentions. The prototypical network has shown superior performance in few-shot NER. However, existing prototypical methods fail to differentiate rich semantics in other-class words, which can lead to overfitting in few-shot scenarios. To address this issue, we introduce a new model, Mining Undefined Classes from Other-class (MUCO), which can automatically induce different undefined classes from the other-class to improve few-shot NER. With these extra-labeled undefined classes, our method will improve the discriminative ability of the NER classifier and enhance understanding of predefined classes with standby semantic knowledge. Experimental results show that our model outperforms five state-of-the-art models in both 1-shot and 5-shot settings on four NER benchmarks. The source code is available on https://github.com/shuaiwa16/OtherClassNER.git.

text: We investigate the task of mining relevant stocks given a topic of concern on emerging capital markets, for which there is lack of structural understanding. Deep learning is leveraged to mine evidences from large scale textual data, which contain valuable market information. In particular, distributed word similarities trained over large scale raw texts are taken as a basis of relevance measuring, and deep reinforcement learning is leveraged to learn a strategy of topic expansion, given a small amount of manually labeled data from financial analysts. Results on two Chinese stock market datasets show that our method outperforms a strong baseline using information retrieval techniques.

label: naacl
text: We are investigating the challenge of identifying relevant stocks in emerging capital markets for a specific topic, where there is a lack of structural understanding. To accomplish this, we utilize deep learning to extract valuable market information from large-scale textual data. Our approach is based on measuring relevance by using distributed word similarities trained on raw texts, and we leverage deep reinforcement learning to learn a strategy for expanding the topic, using only a small amount of manually labeled data from financial analysts. Our results, based on two Chinese stock market datasets, demonstrate that our method outperforms a strong baseline using information retrieval techniques.

text: Following each patient visit, physicians draft long semi-structured clinical summaries called SOAP notes. While invaluable to clinicians and researchers, creating digital SOAP notes is burdensome, contributing to physician burnout. In this paper, we introduce the first complete pipelines to leverage deep summarization models to generate these notes based on transcripts of conversations between physicians and patients. After exploring a spectrum of methods across the extractive-abstractive spectrum, we propose Cluster2Sent, an algorithm that (i) extracts important utterances relevant to each summary section; (ii) clusters together related utterances; and then (iii) generates one summary sentence per cluster. Cluster2Sent outperforms its purely abstractive counterpart by 8 ROUGE-1 points, and produces significantly more factual and coherent sentences as assessed by expert human evaluators. For reproducibility, we demonstrate similar benefits on the publicly available AMI dataset. Our results speak to the benefits of structuring summaries into sections and annotating supporting evidence when constructing summarization corpora.

text: Following each patient visit, physicians create long, semi-structured clinical summaries known as SOAP notes. Although these notes are essential for clinicians and researchers, the process of creating digital SOAP notes is time-consuming and contributes to physician burnout. In this paper, we present the first complete pipeline that leverages deep summarization models to generate these notes based on transcripts of physician-patient conversations. We explore a range of methods along the extractive-abstractive spectrum and propose Cluster2Sent, an algorithm that (1) extracts relevant utterances for each summary section, (2) clusters related utterances together, and (3) generates a summary sentence for each cluster. Cluster2Sent outperforms its purely abstractive counterpart by 8 ROUGE-1 points and produces more factual and coherent sentences, as evaluated by expert human evaluators. We demonstrate similar benefits on the publicly available AMI dataset for reproducibility. Our results highlight the importance of structuring summaries into sections and annotating supporting evidence when constructing summarization corpora.

text: Modern unsupervised machine translation (MT) systems reach reasonable translation quality under clean and controlled data conditions. As the performance gap between supervised and unsupervised MT narrows, it is interesting to ask whether the different training methods result in systematically different output beyond what is visible via quality metrics like adequacy or BLEU. We compare translations from supervised and unsupervised MT systems of similar quality, finding that unsupervised output is more fluent and more structurally different in comparison to human translation than is supervised MT. We then demonstrate a way to combine the benefits of both methods into a single system which results in improved adequacy and fluency as rated by human evaluators. Our results open the door to interesting discussions about how supervised and unsupervised MT might be different yet mutually-beneficial.

label: naacl
text: The modern unsupervised machine translation (MT) systems produce reasonable quality translations under controlled and clean data conditions. As the performance gap between supervised and unsupervised MT narrows, it is worth exploring whether the different training methods lead to systematically different outputs beyond what is reflected in quality metrics such as adequacy or BLEU. Our comparison of translations from supervised and unsupervised MT systems of similar quality reveals that unsupervised output is more fluent and structurally different from human translation compared to supervised MT. We then present a method for combining the advantages of both methods into a single system, resulting in improved adequacy and fluency as rated by human evaluators. Our findings open up exciting avenues for discussion on how supervised and unsupervised MT can complement each other.

text: Sentence compression condenses a sentence while preserving its most important contents. Delete-based models have the strong ability to delete undesired words, while generate-based models are able to reorder or rephrase the words, which are more coherent to human sentence compression. In this paper, we propose Operation Network, a neural network approach for abstractive sentence compression, which combines the advantages of both delete-based and generate-based sentence compression models. The central idea of Operation Network is to model the sentence compression process as an editing procedure. First, unnecessary words are deleted from the source sentence, then new words are either generated from a large vocabulary or copied directly from the source sentence. A compressed sentence can be obtained by a series of such edit operations (delete, copy and generate). Experiments show that Operation Network outperforms state-of-the-art baselines.

label: coling
text: In this paper, we present Operation Network, a neural network approach for abstractive sentence compression that combines the strengths of delete-based and generate-based models. Our approach models sentence compression as an editing process, where unnecessary words are deleted, new words are generated or copied, and a compressed sentence is obtained through a series of these operations. The results of our experiments demonstrate that Operation Network outperforms existing state-of-the-art models.

label: emnlp
text: Image paragraph captioning models aim to produce detailed descriptions of a source image. These models use similar techniques as standard image captioning models, but they have encountered issues in text generation, notably a lack of diversity between sentences, that have limited their effectiveness. In this work, we consider applying sequence-level training for this task. We find that standard self-critical training produces poor results, but when combined with an integrated penalty on trigram repetition produces much more diverse paragraphs. This simple training approach improves on the best result on the Visual Genome paragraph captioning dataset from 16.9 to 30.6 CIDEr, with gains on METEOR and BLEU as well, without requiring any architectural changes.

label: emnlp
text: The aim of image paragraph captioning models is to generate detailed descriptions of a source image. Despite using similar techniques as standard image captioning models, they have struggled with text generation, particularly with a lack of diversity between sentences. To address this issue, we explore the application of sequence-level training for this task. Our results indicate that standard self-critical training alone produces inadequate results, but when combined with a penalty on trigram repetition, it leads to much more diverse paragraphs. This simple training approach significantly improves the best result on the Visual Genome paragraph captioning dataset, increasing it from 16.9 to 30.6 CIDEr, and also yielding improvements in METEOR and BLEU scores, without requiring any changes to the model architecture.

label: coling
text: Recent advances in commonsense reasoning have been fueled by the availability of large-scale human annotated datasets. Manual annotation of such datasets, many of which are based on existing knowledge bases, is expensive and not scalable. Moreover, it is challenging to build augmentation data for commonsense reasoning because the synthetic questions need to adhere to real-world scenarios. Hence, we present GraDA, a graph-generative data augmentation framework to synthesize factual data samples from knowledge graphs for commonsense reasoning datasets. First, we train a graph-to-text model for conditional generation of questions from graph entities and relations. Then, we train a generator with GAN loss to generate distractors for synthetic questions. Our approach improves performance for SocialIQA, CODAH, HellaSwag and CommonsenseQA, and works well for generative tasks like ProtoQA. We show improvement in robustness to semantic adversaries after training with GraDA and provide human evaluation of the quality of synthetic datasets in terms of factuality and answerability. Our work provides evidence and encourages future research into graph-based generative data augmentation.

text: Recent advances in commonsense reasoning have been driven by the availability of large-scale, human-annotated datasets. However, manual annotation of these datasets, many of which are based on existing knowledge bases, is costly and not feasible at scale. Additionally, creating augmentation data for commonsense reasoning is challenging because the synthetic questions must be based on real-world scenarios. To address these issues, we introduce GraDA, a graph-based data augmentation framework that synthesizes factual data samples from knowledge graphs for commonsense reasoning datasets. Our framework consists of two steps: first, we train a graph-to-text model to generate questions from graph entities and relations, and second, we use a generator with a GAN loss to generate distractors for the synthetic questions. Our approach has shown improvement in the performance of SocialIQA, CODAH, HellaSwag, and CommonsenseQA and works well for generative tasks like ProtoQA. Furthermore, our results demonstrate an increase in robustness to semantic adversaries when trained with GraDA, and we provide human evaluations of the quality of the synthetic datasets in terms of factuality and answerability. Our work provides compelling evidence and motivates further research into graph-based data augmentation.

label: naacl
text: Neural module networks (NMN) have achieved success in image-grounded tasks such as Visual Question Answering (VQA) on synthetic images. However, very limited work on NMN has been studied in the video-grounded dialogue tasks. These tasks extend the complexity of traditional visual tasks with the additional visual temporal variance and language cross-turn dependencies. Motivated by recent NMN approaches on image-grounded tasks, we introduce Video-grounded Neural Module Network (VGNMN) to model the information retrieval process in video-grounded language tasks as a pipeline of neural modules. VGNMN first decomposes all language components in dialogues to explicitly resolve any entity references and detect corresponding action-based inputs from the question. The detected entities and actions are used as parameters to instantiate neural module networks and extract visual cues from the video. Our experiments show that VGNMN can achieve promising performance on a challenging video-grounded dialogue benchmark as well as a video QA benchmark.

label: naacl
text: Neural module networks (NMN) have been successful in image-grounded tasks, such as Visual Question Answering (VQA) on synthetic images. However, limited work has been done on NMN in video-grounded dialogue tasks, which are more complex due to the additional visual temporal variance and language cross-turn dependencies. To address this, we introduce the Video-grounded Neural Module Network (VGNMN) to model the information retrieval process in video-grounded language tasks as a pipeline of neural modules. VGNMN decomposes language components in dialogues to explicitly resolve entity references and detect corresponding action-based inputs from the questions. The detected entities and actions are used to instantiate neural module networks and extract visual cues from the video. Our experiments show that VGNMN performs well on challenging video-grounded dialogue and video QA benchmarks.

label: coling
text: Traditional topic models are insufficient for topic extraction in social media. The existing methods only consider text information or simultaneously model the posts and the static characteristics of social media. They ignore that one discusses diverse topics when dynamically interacting with different people. Moreover, people who talk about the same topic have different effects on the topic. In this paper, we propose an Interaction-Aware Topic Model (IATM) for microblog conversations by integrating network embedding and user attention. A conversation network linking users based on reposting and replying relationship is constructed to mine the dynamic user behaviours. We model dynamic interactions and user attention so as to learn interaction-aware edge embeddings with social context. Then they are incorporated into neural variational inference for generating the more consistent topics. The experiments on three real-world datasets show that our proposed model is effective.

label: coling
text: Traditional topic models are inadequate for extracting topics in social media. Existing methods only consider text information, or model both posts and static characteristics of social media simultaneously. They overlook the fact that people discuss diverse topics when interacting with different individuals. Additionally, people who discuss the same topic may have varying impacts on the topic. In this paper, we present an Interaction-Aware Topic Model (IATM) for microblog conversations, which integrates network embedding and user attention. Our model is based on a conversation network that links users through reposting and replying relationships, allowing us to mine dynamic user behavior. We also model dynamic interactions and user attention to generate interaction-aware edge embeddings that incorporate social context. These embeddings are then incorporated into a neural variational inference model to produce more consistent topics. Our experiments on three real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed model.

label: acl
text: Novel neural models have been proposed in recent years for learning under domain shift. Most models, however, only evaluate on a single task, on proprietary datasets, or compare to weak baselines, which makes comparison of models difficult. In this paper, we re-evaluate classic general-purpose bootstrapping approaches in the context of neural networks under domain shifts vs. recent neural approaches and propose a novel multi-task tri-training method that reduces the time and space complexity of classic tri-training. Extensive experiments on two benchmarks for part-of-speech tagging and sentiment analysis are negative: while our novel method establishes a new state-of-the-art for sentiment analysis, it does not fare consistently the best. More importantly, we arrive at the somewhat surprising conclusion that classic tri-training, with some additions, outperforms the state-of-the-art for NLP. Hence classic approaches constitute an important and strong baseline.

label: acl
text: Recently, various novel neural models have been proposed for learning under domain shifts. However, the majority of these models only evaluate their performance on a single task, using proprietary datasets, or comparing to weak baselines, making it challenging to compare the models. In this study, we reassess the classic general-purpose bootstrapping methods in the context of neural networks under domain shifts and recent neural approaches. Additionally, we introduce a novel multi-task tri-training method that reduces the complexity of classic tri-training in terms of time and space. Our extensive experiments on two benchmark datasets for part-of-speech tagging and sentiment analysis yield mixed results. While our novel method sets a new state-of-the-art for sentiment analysis, it does not consistently perform the best. More significantly, we find that, with some modifications, classic tri-training outperforms the state-of-the-art in NLP, making it a strong and important baseline.

label: coling
text: Existing video understanding datasets mostly focus on human interactions, with little attention being paid to the “in the wild” settings, where the videos are recorded outdoors. We propose WILDQA, a video understanding dataset of videos recorded in outside settings. In addition to video question answering (Video QA), we also introduce the new task of identifying visual support for a given question and answer (Video Evidence Selection). Through evaluations using a wide range of baseline models, we show that WILDQA poses new challenges to the vision and language research communities. The dataset is available at https: //lit.eecs.umich.edu/wildqa/.

label: coling
text: Existing video understanding datasets primarily concentrate on human interactions, neglecting the significance of "in the wild" settings where videos are recorded in outdoor environments. To address this gap, we present WILDQA, a novel video understanding dataset that captures videos recorded in outdoor settings. Beyond traditional video question answering (Video QA), WILDQA also introduces a new task of identifying visual support for a given question and answer (Video Evidence Selection). Our evaluation results, based on a wide range of baseline models, demonstrate that WILDQA presents new challenges to both the vision and language research communities. The dataset can be accessed at https://lit.eecs.umich.edu/wildqa/.
