text: We present a large-scale collection of diverse natural language inference (NLI) datasets that help provide insight into how well a sentence representation captures distinct types of reasoning. The collection results from recasting 13 existing datasets from 7 semantic phenomena into a common NLI structure, resulting in over half a million labeled context-hypothesis pairs in total. We refer to our collection as the DNC: Diverse Natural Language Inference Collection. The DNC is available online at https://www.decomp.net, and will grow over time as additional resources are recast and added from novel sources.

label: emnlp
text: We present the DNC, a large-scale collection of diverse Natural Language Inference (NLI) datasets aimed at providing insight into the effectiveness of sentence representation in capturing various types of reasoning. The DNC is a result of recasting 13 existing datasets from 7 semantic phenomena into a common NLI structure, resulting in over 500,000 labeled context-hypothesis pairs. The collection is available online at https://www.decomp.net and will continue to grow as additional resources are added from new sources.

text: Unsupervised cross-lingual projection for part-of-speech (POS) tagging relies on the use of parallel data to project POS tags from a source language for which a POS tagger is available onto a target language across word-level alignments. The projected tags then form the basis for learning a POS model for the target language. However, languages with rich morphology often yield sparse word alignments because words corresponding to the same citation form do not align well. We hypothesize that for morphologically complex languages, it is more efficient to use the stem rather than the word as the core unit of abstraction. Our contributions are: 1) we propose an unsupervised stem-based cross-lingual approach for POS tagging for low-resource languages of rich morphology; 2) we further investigate morpheme-level alignment and projection; and 3) we examine whether the use of linguistic priors for morphological segmentation improves POS tagging. We conduct experiments using six source languages and eight morphologically complex target languages of diverse typologies. Our results show that the stem-based approach improves the POS models for all the target languages, with an average relative error reduction of 10.3% in accuracy per target language, and outperforms the word-based approach that operates on three-times more data for about two thirds of the language pairs we consider. Moreover, we show that morpheme-level alignment and projection and the use of linguistic priors for morphological segmentation further improve POS tagging.

text: The unsupervised cross-lingual projection method for part-of-speech (POS) tagging uses parallel data to project POS tags from a source language, for which a POS tagger is available, onto a target language based on word-level alignments. This projected data is then used to train a POS model for the target language. However, languages with rich morphologies often have sparse word alignments because words with the same citation form do not align well. To address this issue, we hypothesize that stem-based abstraction is more efficient for morphologically complex languages. Our research focuses on: 1) proposing an unsupervised stem-based cross-lingual approach for POS tagging in low-resource languages with rich morphologies; 2) exploring morpheme-level alignment and projection; and 3) examining the impact of linguistic priors for morphological segmentation on POS tagging. Our experiments use six source languages and eight morphologically complex target languages of varying typologies. Results show that the stem-based approach improves the accuracy of the POS models for all target languages, with an average relative error reduction of 10.3%, outperforming the word-based approach that operates on three times more data for two-thirds of the language pairs we consider. Additionally, our findings indicate that morpheme-level alignment and projection, as well as the use of linguistic priors for morphological segmentation, further improve POS tagging.

text: In this paper, we extend the line of BERTology work by focusing on the important, yet less explored, alignment of pre-trained and fine-tuned PLMs with large-scale discourse structures. We propose a novel approach to infer discourse information for arbitrarily long documents. In our experiments, we find that the captured discourse information is local and general, even across a collection of fine-tuning tasks. We compare the inferred discourse trees with supervised, distantly supervised and simple baselines to explore the structural overlap, finding that constituency discourse trees align well with supervised models, however, contain complementary discourse information.Lastly, we individually explore self-attention matrices to analyze the information redundancy. We find that similar discourse information is consistently captured in the same heads.

text: This paper extends the existing research on BERTology by focusing on the crucial, yet under-investigated, alignment between pre-trained and fine-tuned language models and large-scale discourse structures. Our novel approach enables us to infer discourse information for documents of any length. Our experiments reveal that the captured discourse information is both local and general, even across different fine-tuning tasks. We compare the inferred discourse trees with supervised, distantly supervised, and simple baseline models to assess the structural overlap, and find that the constituency discourse trees align well with supervised models, but also contain additional discourse information. Finally, we analyze the information redundancy in the self-attention matrices, discovering that similar discourse information is consistently captured in the same heads.

text: Recent works on knowledge base question answering (KBQA) retrieve subgraphs for easier reasoning. The desired subgraph is crucial as a small one may exclude the answer but a large one might introduce more noises. However, the existing retrieval is either heuristic or interwoven with the reasoning, causing reasoning on the partial subgraphs, which increases the reasoning bias when the intermediate supervision is missing. This paper proposes a trainable subgraph retriever (SR) decoupled from the subsequent reasoning process, which enables a plug-and-play framework to enhance any subgraph-oriented KBQA model. Extensive experiments demonstrate SR achieves significantly better retrieval and QA performance than existing retrieval methods. Via weakly supervised pre-training as well as the end-to-end fine-tuning, SR achieves new state-of-the-art performance when combined with NSM (He et al., 2021), a subgraph-oriented reasoner, for embedding-based KBQA methods. Codes and datasets are available online (https://github.com/RUCKBReasoning/SubgraphRetrievalKBQA)

text: Recent works of opinion expression identification (OEI) rely heavily on the quality and scale of the manually-constructed training corpus, which could be extremely difficult to satisfy. Crowdsourcing is one practical solution for this problem, aiming to create a large-scale but quality-unguaranteed corpus. In this work, we investigate Chinese OEI with extremely-noisy crowdsourcing annotations, constructing a dataset at a very low cost. Following Zhang el al. (2021), we train the annotator-adapter model by regarding all annotations as gold-standard in terms of crowd annotators, and test the model by using a synthetic expert, which is a mixture of all annotators. As this annotator-mixture for testing is never modeled explicitly in the training phase, we propose to generate synthetic training samples by a pertinent mixup strategy to make the training and testing highly consistent. The simulation experiments on our constructed dataset show that crowdsourcing is highly promising for OEI, and our proposed annotator-mixup can further enhance the crowdsourcing modeling.

text: The recent works on Opinion Expression Identification (OEI) are heavily dependent on the quality and quantity of the manually constructed training corpus, which can be challenging to obtain. Crowdsourcing is a practical solution to this problem, as it can create a large-scale corpus, albeit with unguaranteed quality. In this study, we examine Chinese OEI using noisy crowdsourced annotations and construct a cost-effective dataset. Following Zhang et al. (2021), we train an annotator-adapter model by treating all annotations as gold-standard from the crowd annotators and test the model using a synthetic expert, which is a combination of all annotators. To ensure consistency between training and testing, we propose a mixup strategy to generate synthetic training samples that reflect the annotator-mixture used for testing. The simulation experiments on our constructed dataset demonstrate the potential of crowdsourcing for OEI and the effectiveness of our annotator-mixup approach in enhancing crowdsourcing modeling.

text: Community Question Answering (CQA) fora such as Stack Overflow and Yahoo! Answers contain a rich resource of answers to a wide range of community-based questions. Each question thread can receive a large number of answers with different perspectives. One goal of answer summarization is to produce a summary that reflects the range of answer perspectives. A major obstacle for this task is the absence of a dataset to provide supervision for producing such summaries. Recent works propose heuristics to create such data, but these are often noisy and do not cover all answer perspectives present. This work introduces a novel dataset of 4,631 CQA threads for answer summarization curated by professional linguists. Our pipeline gathers annotations for all subtasks of answer summarization, including relevant answer sentence selection, grouping these sentences based on perspectives, summarizing each perspective, and producing an overall summary. We analyze and benchmark state-of-the-art models on these subtasks and introduce a novel unsupervised approach for multi-perspective data augmentation that boosts summarization performance according to automatic evaluation. Finally, we propose reinforcement learning rewards to improve factual consistency and answer coverage and analyze areas for improvement.

text: Community Question Answering (CQA) platforms such as Stack Overflow and Yahoo! Answers are a rich source of answers to a wide range of questions asked by the community. Each question thread can attract a large number of answers, each with a different perspective. The goal of answer summarization is to create a summary that captures the range of perspectives. The main challenge in this task is the lack of a dataset to provide guidance for creating such summaries. Previous works have proposed heuristics to create datasets, but these are often noisy and do not cover all perspectives. This study introduces a new dataset of 4,631 CQA threads for answer summarization, which was curated by professional linguists. The pipeline includes annotations for all subtasks of answer summarization, including the selection of relevant answer sentences, grouping sentences based on perspectives, summarizing each perspective, and producing an overall summary. We evaluate the performance of state-of-the-art models on these subtasks and present a novel unsupervised approach for multi-perspective data augmentation that improves summarization performance as evaluated by automatic metrics. Finally, we propose reinforcement learning rewards to improve factual consistency and answer coverage and identify areas for improvement.

label: emnlp
text: Neural conversation models tend to generate safe, generic responses for most inputs. This is due to the limitations of likelihood-based decoding objectives in generation tasks with diverse outputs, such as conversation. To address this challenge, we propose a simple yet effective approach for incorporating side information in the form of distributional constraints over the generated responses. We propose two constraints that help generate more content rich responses that are based on a model of syntax and topics (Griffiths et al., 2005) and semantic similarity (Arora et al., 2016). We evaluate our approach against a variety of competitive baselines, using both automatic metrics and human judgments, showing that our proposed approach generates responses that are much less generic without sacrificing plausibility. A working demo of our code can be found at https://github.com/abaheti95/DC-NeuralConversation.

text: Neural conversation models often produce safe, generic responses for most inputs because of the limitations of likelihood-based decoding objectives in generation tasks with diverse outputs. To overcome this challenge, we introduce a simple yet effective approach that incorporates side information in the form of distributional constraints. Our approach involves two constraints, which are based on a syntax and topic model (Griffiths et al., 2005) and semantic similarity (Arora et al., 2016). Our approach outperforms competitive baselines, as demonstrated by both automatic metrics and human evaluations. The generated responses are less generic and more content-rich, without compromising their plausibility. A demo of our code is available at https://github.com/abaheti95/DC-NeuralConversation.

text: Named Entity Recognition (NER) is the task of identifying spans that represent entities in sentences. Whether the entity spans are nested or discontinuous, the NER task can be categorized into the flat NER, nested NER, and discontinuous NER subtasks. These subtasks have been mainly solved by the token-level sequence labelling or span-level classification. However, these solutions can hardly tackle the three kinds of NER subtasks concurrently. To that end, we propose to formulate the NER subtasks as an entity span sequence generation task, which can be solved by a unified sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) framework. Based on our unified framework, we can leverage the pre-trained Seq2Seq model to solve all three kinds of NER subtasks without the special design of the tagging schema or ways to enumerate spans. We exploit three types of entity representations to linearize entities into a sequence. Our proposed framework is easy-to-implement and achieves state-of-the-art (SoTA) or near SoTA performance on eight English NER datasets, including two flat NER datasets, three nested NER datasets, and three discontinuous NER datasets.

text: Named Entity Recognition (NER) is the process of identifying entities in sentences, such as person names, organizations, and locations. This task can be divided into three subtasks: flat NER, nested NER, and discontinuous NER. These subtasks have traditionally been solved using token-level sequence labeling or span-level classification. However, these solutions cannot effectively handle all three subtasks simultaneously. To address this issue, we propose a new approach that formulates NER as an entity span sequence generation task, which can be solved using a unified sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) framework. This framework allows us to leverage pre-trained Seq2Seq models to solve all three subtasks without the need for specialized tagging schemas or enumeration methods. We use three types of entity representations to linearize entities into sequences. Our framework is easy to implement and achieves state-of-the-art or near state-of-the-art performance on eight English NER datasets, including two flat NER datasets, three nested NER datasets, and three discontinuous NER datasets.

text: In this paper, we propose to leverage the unique characteristics of dialogues sharing commonsense knowledge across participants, to resolve the difficulties in summarizing them. We present SICK, a framework that uses commonsense inferences as additional context. Compared to previous work that solely relies on the input dialogue, SICK uses an external knowledge model to generate a rich set of commonsense inferences and selects the most probable one with a similarity-based selection method. Built upon SICK, SICK++ utilizes commonsense as supervision, where the task of generating commonsense inferences is added upon summarizing the dialogue in a multi-task learning setting. Experimental results show that with injected commonsense knowledge, our framework generates more informative and consistent summaries than existing methods.

label: coling
text: In this paper, we propose a framework, SICK, to leverage the unique characteristics of dialogues that involve sharing commonsense knowledge among participants to overcome the challenges of summarizing them. SICK uses commonsense inferences as additional context, by incorporating an external knowledge model to generate a rich set of commonsense inferences and selecting the most probable one using a similarity-based selection method. To further enhance the framework, we introduce SICK++, which utilizes commonsense as supervision in a multi-task learning setting. The results of our experiments demonstrate that SICK++, with its injected commonsense knowledge, generates more informative and consistent summaries than existing methods.

text: Lexical simplification (LS) is the task of automatically replacing complex words for easier ones making texts more accessible to various target populations (e.g. individuals with low literacy, individuals with learning disabilities, second language learners). To train and test models, LS systems usually require corpora that feature complex words in context along with their potential substitutions. To continue improving the performance of LS systems we introduce ALEXSIS-PT, a novel multi-candidate dataset for Brazilian Portuguese LS containing 9,605 candidate substitutions for 387 complex words. ALEXSIS-PT has been compiled following the ALEXSIS-ES protocol for Spanish opening exciting new avenues for cross-lingual models. ALEXSIS-PT is the first LS multi-candidate dataset that contains Brazilian newspaper articles. We evaluated three models for substitute generation on this dataset, namely mBERT, XLM-R, and BERTimbau. The latter achieved the highest performance across all evaluation metrics.

text: The task of Lexical Simplification (LS) involves automatically replacing complex words with simpler ones to make texts more accessible to target populations such as individuals with low literacy, learning disabilities, or second language learners. LS systems typically require corpora that include complex words in context and their potential substitutions to train and test models. To further improve LS performance, we present ALEXSIS-PT, a new multi-candidate dataset for Brazilian Portuguese LS, containing 9,605 candidate substitutions for 387 complex words. This dataset was compiled using the ALEXSIS-ES protocol for Spanish, providing exciting opportunities for cross-lingual models. ALEXSIS-PT is the first LS multi-candidate dataset that includes articles from Brazilian newspapers. We evaluated three substitute generation models on this dataset, including mBERT, XLM-R, and BERTimbau. BERTimbau achieved the highest performance across all evaluation metrics.

text: Recent studies on the lottery ticket hypothesis (LTH) show that pre-trained language models (PLMs) like BERT contain matching subnetworks that have similar transfer learning performance as the original PLM. These subnetworks are found using magnitude-based pruning. In this paper, we find that the BERT subnetworks have even more potential than these studies have shown. Firstly, we discover that the success of magnitude pruning can be attributed to the preserved pre-training performance, which correlates with the downstream transferability. Inspired by this, we propose to directly optimize the subnetwork structure towards the pre-training objectives, which can better preserve the pre-training performance. Specifically, we train binary masks over model weights on the pre-training tasks, with the aim of preserving the universal transferability of the subnetwork, which is agnostic to any specific downstream tasks. We then fine-tune the subnetworks on the GLUE benchmark and the SQuAD dataset. The results show that, compared with magnitude pruning, mask training can effectively find BERT subnetworks with improved overall performance on downstream tasks. Moreover, our method is also more efficient in searching subnetworks and more advantageous when fine-tuning within a certain range of data scarcity. Our code is available at https://github.com/llyx97/TAMT.

text: Recent studies have shown that pre-trained language models (PLMs) like BERT contain matching subnetworks with similar transfer learning performance as the original PLM, which were discovered through magnitude-based pruning. However, this paper reveals that these subnetworks have even more potential. Our research found that the success of magnitude pruning is due to the preservation of pre-training performance, which is directly related to transferability. Based on this insight, we propose a new method of directly optimizing the subnetwork structure to preserve pre-training performance. This is achieved by training binary masks over model weights on pre-training tasks, with the goal of preserving the subnetwork's universal transferability, regardless of the downstream task. Our results, obtained by fine-tuning the subnetworks on the GLUE benchmark and the SQuAD dataset, show that mask training is more effective in finding BERT subnetworks with improved overall performance on downstream tasks, and is more efficient and advantageous in cases of data scarcity. The code for our method is available at https://github.com/llyx97/TAMT.

text: For emerging events, human readers are often exposed to both real news and fake news. Multiple news articles may contain complementary or contradictory information that readers can leverage to help detect fake news. Inspired by this process, we propose a novel task of cross-document misinformation detection. Given a cluster of topically related news documents, we aim to detect misinformation at both document level and a more fine-grained level, event level. Due to the lack of data, we generate fake news by manipulating real news, and construct 3 new datasets with 422, 276, and 1,413 clusters of topically related documents, respectively. We further propose a graph-based detector that constructs a cross-document knowledge graph using cross-document event coreference resolution and employs a heterogeneous graph neural network to conduct detection at two levels. We then feed the event-level detection results into the document-level detector. Experimental results show that our proposed method significantly outperforms existing methods by up to 7 F1 points on this new task.

text: Emerging events often expose human readers to both real and fake news. To help detect fake news, readers can leverage multiple news articles that may contain complementary or contradictory information. We propose a novel task of cross-document misinformation detection, which involves identifying misinformation at both the document and event levels. To address the lack of data, we generated fake news by manipulating real news and constructed three datasets with 422, 276, and 1,413 clusters of related documents. Our graph-based detector uses cross-document event coreference resolution and a heterogeneous graph neural network to conduct detection at both levels. Our results show that our method outperforms existing methods by up to 7 F1 points.

text: Semantic typing aims at classifying tokens or spans of interest in a textual context into semantic categories such as relations, entity types, and event types. The inferred labels of semantic categories meaningfully interpret how machines understand components of text. In this paper, we present UniST, a unified framework for semantic typing that captures label semantics by projecting both inputs and labels into a joint semantic embedding space. To formulate different lexical and relational semantic typing tasks as a unified task, we incorporate task descriptions to be jointly encoded with the input, allowing UniST to be adapted to different tasks without introducing task-specific model components. UniST optimizes a margin ranking loss such that the semantic relatedness of the input and labels is reflected from their embedding similarity. Our experiments demonstrate that UniST achieves strong performance across three semantic typing tasks: entity typing, relation classification and event typing. Meanwhile, UniST effectively transfers semantic knowledge of labels and substantially improves generalizability on inferring rarely seen and unseen types. In addition, multiple semantic typing tasks can be jointly trained within the unified framework, leading to a single compact multi-tasking model that performs comparably to dedicated single-task models, while offering even better transferability.

text: The aim of semantic typing is to categorize tokens or spans of text into semantic categories, such as relations, entity types, and event types, in order to interpret how machines understand the components of text. In this paper, we introduce UniST, a unified framework for semantic typing that captures label semantics by projecting inputs and labels into a joint semantic embedding space. UniST formulates different lexical and relational semantic typing tasks as a unified task by incorporating task descriptions, allowing it to be adapted to different tasks without adding task-specific components. UniST optimizes a margin ranking loss to reflect the semantic relatedness of inputs and labels through their embedding similarity. Our experiments show that UniST outperforms other models in three semantic typing tasks: entity typing, relation classification, and event typing. It also transfers semantic knowledge of labels effectively and improves generalizability in recognizing rarely seen and unseen types. Furthermore, UniST can jointly train multiple semantic typing tasks, resulting in a single compact multi-tasking model that performs as well as dedicated single-task models while offering better transferability.

text: Distributional models learn representations of words from text, but are criticized for their lack of grounding, or the linking of text to the non-linguistic world. Grounded language models have had success in learning to connect concrete categories like nouns and adjectives to the world via images and videos, but can struggle to isolate the meaning of the verbs themselves from the context in which they typically occur. In this paper, we investigate the extent to which trajectories (i.e. the position and rotation of objects over time) naturally encode verb semantics. We build a procedurally generated agent-object-interaction dataset, obtain human annotations for the verbs that occur in this data, and compare several methods for representation learning given the trajectories. We find that trajectories correlate as-is with some verbs (e.g., fall), and that additional abstraction via self-supervised pretraining can further capture nuanced differences in verb meaning (e.g., roll and slide).

text: Distributional models are used to learn representations of words from text, but they are criticized for their lack of grounding, meaning the absence of a connection between the text and the non-linguistic world. Grounded language models have had success in linking concrete categories like nouns and adjectives to the world via images and videos, but they struggle to isolate the meaning of verbs from the context in which they occur. In this paper, we explore the extent to which trajectories - the position and rotation of objects over time - naturally encode verb semantics. We create a procedurally generated agent-object-interaction dataset and obtain human annotations for the verbs in the data. Then, we compare several methods for representation learning based on trajectories. Our results show that trajectories alone can correlate with some verbs (e.g., fall), and that self-supervised pretraining can further capture nuanced differences in verb meaning (e.g., roll and slide).

text: Semantic relations are often signaled with prepositional or possessive marking—but extreme polysemy bedevils their analysis and automatic interpretation. We introduce a new annotation scheme, corpus, and task for the disambiguation of prepositions and possessives in English. Unlike previous approaches, our annotations are comprehensive with respect to types and tokens of these markers; use broadly applicable supersense classes rather than fine-grained dictionary definitions; unite prepositions and possessives under the same class inventory; and distinguish between a marker's lexical contribution and the role it marks in the context of a predicate or scene. Strong interannotator agreement rates, as well as encouraging disambiguation results with established supervised methods, speak to the viability of the scheme and task.

label: acl
text: Semantic relations are often indicated by prepositions or possessive markers, but the analysis and automatic interpretation of these markers is challenging due to the high degree of polysemy. To address this issue, we present a new annotation scheme, corpus, and task for disambiguating prepositions and possessives in English. Our approach is comprehensive, covering both types and tokens of these markers, and uses broadly applicable supersense classes instead of fine-grained dictionary definitions. Additionally, our scheme unites prepositions and possessives into a single class inventory and distinguishes between a marker's lexical contribution and its role in the context of a predicate or scene. Our high interannotator agreement rates and promising disambiguation results using established supervised methods demonstrate the viability of our scheme and task.

label: acl
text: Ordinal Classification (OC) is an important classification task where the classes are ordinal. For example, an OC task for sentiment analysis could have the following classes: highly positive, positive, neutral, negative, highly negative. Clearly, evaluation measures for an OC task should penalise misclassifications by considering the ordinal nature of the classes. Ordinal Quantification (OQ) is a related task where the gold data is a distribution over ordinal classes, and the system is required to estimate this distribution. Evaluation measures for an OQ task should also take the ordinal nature of the classes into account. However, for both OC and OQ, there are only a small number of known evaluation measures that meet this basic requirement. In the present study, we utilise data from the SemEval and NTCIR communities to clarify the properties of nine evaluation measures in the context of OC tasks, and six measures in the context of OQ tasks.

text: Ordinal Classification (OC) is a crucial classification task where the classes are ordered. For instance, a sentiment analysis OC task might have the following classes: highly positive, positive, neutral, negative, highly negative. The evaluation measures for an OC task should consider the ordinal nature of the classes and penalize misclassifications accordingly. Ordinal Quantification (OQ) is a related task where the gold standard data is a distribution across ordered classes, and the system must estimate this distribution. The evaluation measures for an OQ task should also reflect the ordinal nature of the classes. However, there are only a limited number of known evaluation measures that meet this requirement. This study uses data from the SemEval and NTCIR communities to examine the properties of nine evaluation measures for OC tasks and six measures for OQ tasks.

text: A well-calibrated neural model produces confidence (probability outputs) closely approximated by the expected accuracy. While prior studies have shown that mixup training as a data augmentation technique can improve model calibration on image classification tasks, little is known about using mixup for model calibration on natural language understanding (NLU) tasks. In this paper, we explore mixup for model calibration on several NLU tasks and propose a novel mixup strategy for pre-trained language models that improves model calibration further. Our proposed mixup is guided by both the Area Under the Margin (AUM) statistic (Pleiss et al., 2020) and the saliency map of each sample (Simonyan et al., 2013). Moreover, we combine our mixup strategy with model miscalibration correction techniques (i.e., label smoothing and temperature scaling) and provide detailed analyses of their impact on our proposed mixup. We focus on systematically designing experiments on three NLU tasks: natural language inference, paraphrase detection, and commonsense reasoning. Our method achieves the lowest expected calibration error compared to strong baselines on both in-domain and out-of-domain test samples while maintaining competitive accuracy.

text: A well-calibrated neural model outputs confidence (probability) that closely matches its expected accuracy. While previous studies have demonstrated that the mixup data augmentation technique can enhance model calibration for image classification tasks, its application to natural language understanding (NLU) tasks is not well understood. In this study, we investigate using mixup for model calibration on various NLU tasks and present a novel mixup strategy for pre-trained language models that further improves calibration. Our mixup approach is guided by both the Area Under the Margin (AUM) statistic and the saliency map of each sample. Additionally, we combine our mixup strategy with model miscalibration correction techniques, such as label smoothing and temperature scaling, and analyze their impact on our proposed mixup. Our experiments are focused on three NLU tasks: natural language inference, paraphrase detection, and commonsense reasoning. Our method achieves the lowest expected calibration error compared to strong baselines on both in-domain and out-of-domain test samples, while maintaining competitive accuracy.

text: With the increasing popularity of smart devices, rumors with multimedia content become more and more common on social networks. The multimedia information usually makes rumors look more convincing. Therefore, finding an automatic approach to verify rumors with multimedia content is a pressing task. Previous rumor verification research only utilizes multimedia as input features. We propose not to use the multimedia content but to find external information in other news platforms pivoting on it. We introduce a new features set, cross-lingual cross-platform features that leverage the semantic similarity between the rumors and the external information. When implemented, machine learning methods utilizing such features achieved the state-of-the-art rumor verification results.

text: With the growing popularity of smart devices, rumors containing multimedia content are becoming increasingly prevalent on social networks. These multimedia elements often make rumors appear more credible, making it a pressing need to find an automatic way to verify these rumors. Previous research on rumor verification only considered multimedia content as input features. Our approach is different, as we do not use the multimedia content itself, but instead find external information on other news platforms that can be used to verify the rumors. We introduce a new set of features, cross-lingual cross-platform features, which leverage the semantic similarity between the rumors and external information. When implemented, machine learning methods utilizing these features have achieved state-of-the-art results in rumor verification.

label: acl
text: In several question answering benchmarks, pretrained models have reached human parity through fine-tuning on an order of 100,000 annotated questions and answers. We explore the more realistic few-shot setting, where only a few hundred training examples are available, and observe that standard models perform poorly, highlighting the discrepancy between current pretraining objectives and question answering. We propose a new pretraining scheme tailored for question answering: recurring span selection. Given a passage with multiple sets of recurring spans, we mask in each set all recurring spans but one, and ask the model to select the correct span in the passage for each masked span. Masked spans are replaced with a special token, viewed as a question representation, that is later used during fine-tuning to select the answer span. The resulting model obtains surprisingly good results on multiple benchmarks (e.g., 72.7 F1 on SQuAD with only 128 training examples), while maintaining competitive performance in the high-resource setting.

label: acl
text: In several question-answering benchmarks, pretrained models have achieved human-level accuracy through fine-tuning on a dataset of 100,000 annotated questions and answers. However, in the more realistic scenario of having only a few hundred training examples available, these models perform poorly, highlighting the gap between current pretraining objectives and question answering. To address this issue, we propose a new pretraining method specifically designed for question answering called Recurring Span Selection. Given a passage containing multiple recurring spans, we mask all but one span in each set and ask the model to identify the correct span in the passage. The selected spans are then replaced with a special token, serving as a question representation, which is later used during fine-tuning to find the answer span. This approach yields impressive results on various benchmarks (e.g., 72.7 F1 on SQuAD with only 128 training examples) while maintaining strong performance in high-resource settings.

text: Bi-directional LSTMs are a powerful tool for text representation. On the other hand, they have been shown to suffer various limitations due to their sequential nature. We investigate an alternative LSTM structure for encoding text, which consists of a parallel state for each word. Recurrent steps are used to perform local and global information exchange between words simultaneously, rather than incremental reading of a sequence of words. Results on various classification and sequence labelling benchmarks show that the proposed model has strong representation power, giving highly competitive performances compared to stacked BiLSTM models with similar parameter numbers.

label: acl
text: Bi-directional LSTMs are an effective tool for text representation, but their sequential nature has been shown to cause limitations. To address this, we propose an alternative LSTM structure for text encoding that features a parallel state for each word. This structure enables the simultaneous exchange of local and global information between words through recurrent steps, rather than the incremental reading of a sequence of words. Our results on various classification and sequence labeling benchmarks demonstrate the proposed model's strong representation power, with highly competitive performance compared to stacked BiLSTM models with similar numbers of parameters.

label: naacl
text: Named entity recognition (NER) in a real-world setting remains challenging and is impacted by factors like text genre, corpus quality, and data availability. NER models trained on CoNLL do not transfer well to other domains, even within the same language. This is especially the case for multi-lingual models when applied to low-resource languages, and is mainly due to missing entity information. We propose an approach that with limited effort and data, addresses the NER knowledge gap across languages and domains. Our novel approach uses a token-level gating layer to augment pre-trained multilingual transformers with gazetteers containing named entities (NE) from a target language or domain.This approach provides the flexibility to jointly integrate both textual and gazetteer information dynamically: entity knowledge from gazetteers is used only when a token's textual representation is insufficient for the NER task.Evaluation on several languages and domains demonstrates: (i) a high mismatch of reported NER performance on CoNLL vs. domain specific datasets, (ii) gazetteers significantly improve NER performance across languages and domains, and (iii) gazetteers can be flexibly incorporated to guide knowledge transfer. On cross-lingual transfer we achieve an improvement over the baseline with F1=+17.6%, and with F1=+21.3% for cross-domain transfer.

label: naacl
text: Named Entity Recognition (NER) remains a challenging task in real-world settings due to factors such as text genre, corpus quality, and data availability. NER models trained on the CoNLL dataset do not perform well when applied to other domains or languages, particularly in low-resource languages where entity information is often missing. To address this NER knowledge gap, we propose a novel approach that uses a token-level gating layer to augment pre-trained multilingual transformers with gazetteers containing named entities from the target language or domain. Our approach provides the flexibility to dynamically integrate both textual and gazetteer information, using gazetteer knowledge only when the token's textual representation is insufficient for the NER task. Evaluation on multiple languages and domains shows that our approach outperforms the baseline, with a 17.6% improvement in cross-lingual transfer and a 21.3% improvement in cross-domain transfer. The results also demonstrate that gazetteers significantly improve NER performance across languages and domains, and can be flexibly incorporated to guide knowledge transfer.

label: acl
text: Medical named entity recognition (NER) and normalization (NEN) are fundamental for constructing knowledge graphs and building QA systems. Existing implementations for medical NER and NEN are suffered from the error propagation between the two tasks. The mispredicted mentions from NER will directly influence the results of NEN. Therefore, the NER module is the bottleneck of the whole system. Besides, the learnable features for both tasks are beneficial to improving the model performance. To avoid the disadvantages of existing models and exploit the generalized representation across the two tasks, we design an end-to-end progressive multi-task learning model for jointly modeling medical NER and NEN in an effective way. There are three level tasks with progressive difficulty in the framework. The progressive tasks can reduce the error propagation with the incremental task settings which implies the lower level tasks gain the supervised signals other than errors from the higher level tasks to improve their performances. Besides, the context features are exploited to enrich the semantic information of entity mentions extracted by NER. The performance of NEN profits from the enhanced entity mention features. The standard entities from knowledge bases are introduced into the NER module for extracting corresponding entity mentions correctly. The empirical results on two publicly available medical literature datasets demonstrate the superiority of our method over nine typical methods.

label: acl
text: Medical named entity recognition (NER) and normalization (NEN) are crucial for creating knowledge graphs and developing QA systems. However, existing implementations for medical NER and NEN are plagued by error propagation between the two tasks. The mispredicted mentions from NER negatively impact the results of NEN and make the NER module the bottleneck of the entire system. To enhance the performance of the model, learnable features for both tasks are necessary. To overcome the limitations of existing models and leverage the generalized representation across both tasks, we propose an end-to-end progressive multi-task learning model that effectively models medical NER and NEN together. The model has three levels of tasks with increasing difficulty, reducing error propagation through incremental task settings. The lower level tasks receive supervised signals other than errors from higher level tasks, improving their performance. Additionally, the model exploits context features to provide semantic information for entity mentions extracted by NER, enhancing the performance of NEN. The NER module also uses standard entities from knowledge bases to correctly extract corresponding entity mentions. Empirical results on two publicly available medical literature datasets show the superiority of our method over nine other typical methods.

label: acl
text: As an important task in sentiment analysis, Multimodal Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (MABSA) has attracted increasing attention inrecent years. However, previous approaches either (i) use separately pre-trained visual and textual models, which ignore the crossmodalalignment or (ii) use vision-language models pre-trained with general pre-training tasks, which are inadequate to identify fine-grainedaspects, opinions, and their alignments across modalities. To tackle these limitations, we propose a task-specific Vision-LanguagePre-training framework for MABSA (VLP-MABSA), which is a unified multimodal encoder-decoder architecture for all the pretrainingand downstream tasks. We further design three types of task-specific pre-training tasks from the language, vision, and multimodalmodalities, respectively. Experimental results show that our approach generally outperforms the state-of-the-art approaches on three MABSA subtasks. Further analysis demonstrates the effectiveness of each pre-training task. The source code is publicly released at https://github.com/NUSTM/VLP-MABSA.

label: acl
text: As a crucial aspect of sentiment analysis, Multimodal Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (MABSA) has gained increasing attention in recent years. However, existing approaches either (i) use separate pre-trained visual and textual models that disregard crossmodal alignment or (ii) use pre-trained vision-language models that are inadequate for identifying fine-grained aspects, opinions, and their alignments across modalities. To address these limitations, we have proposed a task-specific Vision-Language Pre-training framework for MABSA (VLP-MABSA), a unified multimodal encoder-decoder architecture that handles both pre-training and downstream tasks. Our framework includes three types of task-specific pre-training tasks from language, vision, and multimodal modalities. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on three MABSA subtasks, and our analysis demonstrates the effectiveness of each pre-training task. The source code is available at https://github.com/NUSTM/VLP-MABSA.

label: acl
text: Recently, question answering (QA) based on machine reading comprehension has become popular. This work focuses on generative QA which aims to generate an abstractive answer to a given question instead of extracting an answer span from a provided passage. Generative QA often suffers from two critical problems: (1) summarizing content irrelevant to a given question, (2) drifting away from a correct answer during generation. In this paper, we address these problems by a novel Rationale-Enriched Answer Generator (REAG), which incorporates an extractive mechanism into a generative model. Specifically, we add an extraction task on the encoder to obtain the rationale for an answer, which is the most relevant piece of text in an input document to a given question. Based on the extracted rationale and original input, the decoder is expected to generate an answer with high confidence. We jointly train REAG on the MS MARCO QA+NLG task and the experimental results show that REAG improves the quality and semantic accuracy of answers over baseline models.

label: acl
text: Recently, question answering (QA) based on machine reading comprehension has gained popularity. This work focuses on generative QA, which aims to generate an abstractive answer to a given question rather than extracting an answer span from a provided passage. However, generative QA often faces two critical problems: (1) summarizing content that is irrelevant to the given question and (2) drifting away from the correct answer during generation. To address these issues, we present a novel Rationale-Enriched Answer Generator (REAG), which integrates an extractive mechanism into a generative model. The REAG uses an extraction task on the encoder to obtain the rationale for an answer, which is the most relevant piece of text in the input document to the given question. The rationale, along with the original input, is then used by the decoder to generate an answer with high confidence. Our experiments, conducted on the MS MARCO QA+NLG task, show that REAG improves the quality and semantic accuracy of answers compared to baseline models.

label: acl
text: A critical challenge faced by supervised word sense disambiguation (WSD) is the lack of large annotated datasets with sufficient coverage of words in their diversity of senses. This inspired recent research on few-shot WSD using meta-learning. While such work has successfully applied meta-learning to learn new word senses from very few examples, its performance still lags behind its fully-supervised counterpart. Aiming to further close this gap, we propose a model of semantic memory for WSD in a meta-learning setting. Semantic memory encapsulates prior experiences seen throughout the lifetime of the model, which aids better generalization in limited data settings. Our model is based on hierarchical variational inference and incorporates an adaptive memory update rule via a hypernetwork. We show our model advances the state of the art in few-shot WSD, supports effective learning in extremely data scarce (e.g. one-shot) scenarios and produces meaning prototypes that capture similar senses of distinct words.

label: acl
text: The biggest challenge facing supervised word sense disambiguation (WSD) is the scarcity of large annotated datasets that cover words in their diverse senses. This has led to recent research in few-shot WSD using meta-learning, which has successfully learned new word senses from just a few examples. However, its performance still lags behind fully-supervised models. To bridge this gap, we present a semantic memory model for WSD in a meta-learning setting. This model uses prior experiences to improve generalization in limited data scenarios, and is based on hierarchical variational inference with an adaptive memory update rule through a hypernetwork. Our model outperforms previous models in few-shot WSD, and is effective even in one-shot scenarios. It also creates meaning prototypes that capture similar senses of different words.

label: acl
text: Commonsense reasoning research has so far been limited to English. We aim to evaluate and improve popular multilingual language models (ML-LMs) to help advance commonsense reasoning (CSR) beyond English. We collect the Mickey corpus, consisting of 561k sentences in 11 different languages, which can be used for analyzing and improving ML-LMs. We propose Mickey Probe, a language-general probing task for fairly evaluating the common sense of popular ML-LMs across different languages. In addition, we also create two new datasets, X-CSQA and X-CODAH, by translating their English versions to 14 other languages, so that we can evaluate popular ML-LMs for cross-lingual commonsense reasoning. To improve the performance beyond English, we propose a simple yet effective method — multilingual contrastive pretraining (MCP). It significantly enhances sentence representations, yielding a large performance gain on both benchmarks (e.g., +2.7% accuracy for X-CSQA over XLM-R_L).

label: acl
text: Limited research has been conducted on commonsense reasoning in English. Our goal is to evaluate and improve popular multilingual language models (ML-LMs) to advance commonsense reasoning beyond English. To achieve this, we have collected the Mickey corpus, a collection of 561k sentences in 11 different languages, which can be used for analyzing and improving ML-LMs. Additionally, we have proposed Mickey Probe, a language-agnostic task for evaluating the common sense of popular ML-LMs across different languages. We have also created two new datasets, X-CSQA and X-CODAH, by translating their English versions into 14 other languages, to evaluate the cross-lingual commonsense reasoning capabilities of popular ML-LMs. To improve performance beyond English, we have proposed a simple yet effective method called multilingual contrastive pretraining (MCP). This method significantly improves sentence representations, resulting in a significant performance gain on both benchmarks, such as a +2.7% accuracy increase on X-CSQA over XLM-R_L.

label: emnlp
text: Statistical phylogenetic models have allowed the quantitative analysis of the evolution of a single categorical feature and a pair of binary features, but correlated evolution involving multiple discrete features is yet to be explored. Here we propose latent representation-based analysis in which (1) a sequence of discrete surface features is projected to a sequence of independent binary variables and (2) phylogenetic inference is performed on the latent space. In the experiments, we analyze the features of linguistic typology, with a special focus on the order of subject, object and verb. Our analysis suggests that languages sharing the same word order are not necessarily a coherent group but exhibit varying degrees of diachronic stability depending on other features.

label: emnlp
text: Statistical phylogenetic models have enabled the quantitative analysis of the evolution of single categorical features and pairs of binary features, but the evolution of multiple discrete features remains under-explored. To address this, we propose a latent representation-based analysis. This involves projecting a sequence of discrete surface features into a sequence of independent binary variables and performing phylogenetic inference on the latent space. Our experiments analyze linguistic typology features, with a focus on the order of subject, object, and verb. Our results indicate that languages sharing the same word order are not necessarily a coherent group, but instead exhibit varying degrees of diachronic stability, depending on other features.

label: acl
text: This paper investigates the construction of a strong baseline based on general purpose sequence-to-sequence models for constituency parsing. We incorporate several techniques that were mainly developed in natural language generation tasks, e.g., machine translation and summarization, and demonstrate that the sequence-to-sequence model achieves the current top-notch parsers' performance (almost) without requiring any explicit task-specific knowledge or architecture of constituent parsing.

label: acl
text: This paper explores the creation of a robust baseline using general-purpose sequence-to-sequence models for constituency parsing. We integrate various techniques, primarily developed for natural language generation tasks such as machine translation and summarization, and show that the sequence-to-sequence model can match the performance of the top-performing parsers without the need for any task-specific knowledge or architecture specific to constituency parsing.

label: naacl
text: A number of differences have emerged between modern and classic approaches to constituency parsing in recent years, with structural components like grammars and feature-rich lexicons becoming less central while recurrent neural network representations rise in popularity. The goal of this work is to analyze the extent to which information provided directly by the model structure in classical systems is still being captured by neural methods. To this end, we propose a high-performance neural model (92.08 F1 on PTB) that is representative of recent work and perform a series of investigative experiments. We find that our model implicitly learns to encode much of the same information that was explicitly provided by grammars and lexicons in the past, indicating that this scaffolding can largely be subsumed by powerful general-purpose neural machinery.

label: naacl
text: In recent years, there has been a growing divide between modern and classic approaches to constituency parsing, with traditional structural components such as grammars and feature-rich lexicons becoming less important, while recurrent neural network representations are gaining popularity. This study aims to evaluate the extent to which information provided by classical systems' model structures is still captured by neural methods. To achieve this, we introduce a high-performing neural model (with a 92.08 F1 score on the PTB dataset) and conduct a series of investigative experiments. Our results show that our model implicitly learns to encode much of the same information that was previously provided explicitly by grammars and lexicons, suggesting that these components can be largely replaced by powerful neural machinery.

label: coling
text: Seq2seq learning has produced promising results on summarization. However, in many cases, system summaries still struggle to keep the meaning of the original intact. They may miss out important words or relations that play critical roles in the syntactic structure of source sentences. In this paper, we present structure-infused copy mechanisms to facilitate copying important words and relations from the source sentence to summary sentence. The approach naturally combines source dependency structure with the copy mechanism of an abstractive sentence summarizer. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of incorporating source-side syntactic information in the system, and our proposed approach compares favorably to state-of-the-art methods.

label: coling
text: Seq2seq learning has shown promising results in summarization, however, system summaries often fail to maintain the meaning of the original text. This is due to missing important words or relationships that play a crucial role in the syntactic structure of the source sentences. To address this issue, we introduce structure-infused copy mechanisms that allow for the copying of critical words and relationships from the source sentence to the summary sentence. Our approach seamlessly integrates source dependency structure with the abstractive summarizer's copy mechanism. The results of our experiments demonstrate the benefits of incorporating source-side syntactic information into the system and our proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods.

label: coling
text: This paper aims to improve the performance of text-to-SQL parsing by exploring the intrinsic uncertainties in the neural network based approaches (called SUN). From the data uncertainty perspective, it is indisputable that a single SQL can be learned from multiple semantically-equivalent questions. Different from previous methods that are limited to one-to-one mapping, we propose a data uncertainty constraint to explore the underlying complementary semantic information among multiple semantically-equivalent questions (many-to-one) and learn the robust feature representations with reduced spurious associations. In this way, we can reduce the sensitivity of the learned representations and improve the robustness of the parser. From the model uncertainty perspective, there is often structural information (dependence) among the weights of neural networks. To improve the generalizability and stability of neural text-to-SQL parsers, we propose a model uncertainty constraint to refine the query representations by enforcing the output representations of different perturbed encoding networks to be consistent with each other. Extensive experiments on five benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms strong competitors and achieves new state-of-the-art results.

label: coling
text: This paper aims to enhance the performance of text-to-SQL parsing by investigating the intrinsic uncertainties in neural network-based approaches (SUN). From a data uncertainty perspective, it is clear that a single SQL can be learned from multiple semantically equivalent questions. Unlike previous methods that are restricted to a one-to-one mapping, we introduce a data uncertainty constraint to examine the complementary semantic information among multiple semantically equivalent questions (many-to-one) and learn robust feature representations with reduced spurious associations. This reduces the sensitivity of the learned representations and improves the parser's robustness. From a model uncertainty perspective, there is often structural information (dependence) among the weights of neural networks. To increase the generalizability and stability of neural text-to-SQL parsers, we propose a model uncertainty constraint to refine the query representations by ensuring that the output representations of different perturbed encoding networks are consistent with each other. Extensive experiments on five benchmark datasets show that our method significantly outperforms strong competitors and achieves new state-of-the-art results.

label: coling
text: Mathematical reasoning task is a subset of the natural language question answering task. Existing work suggested solving this task with a two-phase approach, where the model first predicts formulas from questions and then calculates answers from such formulas. This approach achieved desirable performance in existing work. However, its reliance on annotated formulas as intermediate labels throughout its training limited its application. In this work, we put forward the idea to enable models to learn optimal formulas autonomously. We proposed Weakly Supervised Formula Learner, a learning framework that drives the formula exploration with weak supervision from the final answers to mathematical problems. Our experiments are conducted on two representative mathematical reasoning datasets MathQA and Math23K. On MathQA, our method outperformed baselines trained on complete yet imperfect formula annotations. On Math23K, our method outperformed other weakly supervised learning methods.

label: coling
text: The task of mathematical reasoning is a subset of natural language question answering. Previous research has suggested solving this task using a two-phase approach, where the model first predicts formulas from questions and then calculates answers from these formulas. This approach has shown desirable performance in previous studies. However, its reliance on annotated formulas as intermediate labels during training limits its applicability. In this work, we present the idea of allowing models to learn optimal formulas autonomously. We propose the Weakly Supervised Formula Learner, a learning framework that guides formula exploration using weak supervision from the final answers to mathematical problems. Our experiments were conducted on two mathematical reasoning datasets, MathQA and Math23K. On MathQA, our method outperformed baselines trained on complete but imperfect formula annotations. On Math23K, our method outperformed other weakly supervised learning methods.

label: coling
text: Scientific literature serves as a high-quality corpus, supporting a lot of Natural Language Processing (NLP) research. However, existing datasets are centered around the English language, which restricts the development of Chinese scientific NLP. In this work, we present CSL, a large-scale Chinese Scientific Literature dataset, which contains the titles, abstracts, keywords and academic fields of 396k papers. To our knowledge, CSL is the first scientific document dataset in Chinese. The CSL can serve as a Chinese corpus. Also, this semi-structured data is a natural annotation that can constitute many supervised NLP tasks. Based on CSL, we present a benchmark to evaluate the performance of models across scientific domain tasks, i.e., summarization, keyword generation and text classification. We analyze the behavior of existing text-to-text models on the evaluation tasks and reveal the challenges for Chinese scientific NLP tasks, which provides a valuable reference for future research. Data and code will be publicly available.

label: coling
text: The scientific literature serves as a valuable corpus for supporting numerous Natural Language Processing (NLP) research projects. However, the majority of existing datasets are focused on the English language, limiting the growth of Chinese scientific NLP. To address this issue, we introduce CSL, a large-scale Chinese Scientific Literature dataset containing 396k papers with titles, abstracts, keywords, and academic fields. To the best of our knowledge, CSL is the first scientific document dataset in Chinese and can serve as a valuable corpus for NLP research. This semi-structured data also provides a natural annotation for various supervised NLP tasks. Based on CSL, we present a benchmark to evaluate the performance of models across scientific domain tasks such as summarization, keyword generation, and text classification. Our analysis of existing text-to-text models on these evaluation tasks highlights the challenges of Chinese scientific NLP and provides a valuable reference for future research. The data and code will be made publicly available.

label: acl
text: Cross-lingual natural language inference (XNLI) is a fundamental task in cross-lingual natural language understanding. Recently this task is commonly addressed by pre-trained cross-lingual language models. Existing methods usually enhance pre-trained language models with additional data, such as annotated parallel corpora. These additional data, however, are rare in practice, especially for low-resource languages. Inspired by recent promising results achieved by prompt-learning, this paper proposes a novel prompt-learning based framework for enhancing XNLI. It reformulates the XNLI problem to a masked language modeling problem by constructing cloze-style questions through cross-lingual templates. To enforce correspondence between different languages, the framework augments a new question for every question using a sampled template in another language and then introduces a consistency loss to make the answer probability distribution obtained from the new question as similar as possible with the corresponding distribution obtained from the original question. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that XNLI models enhanced by our proposed framework significantly outperform original ones under both the full-shot and few-shot cross-lingual transfer settings.

label: acl
text: Cross-lingual natural language inference (XNLI) is a key aspect of cross-lingual natural language understanding. Pre-trained cross-lingual language models are commonly used to address this task. However, existing methods often rely on additional data, such as annotated parallel corpora, which can be scarce, especially for low-resource languages. This paper presents a novel prompt-learning-based framework for enhancing XNLI. The framework transforms XNLI into a masked language modeling problem by creating cloze-style questions through cross-lingual templates. To ensure consistency between languages, the framework generates a new question for each original question using a randomly selected template in another language and imposes a consistency loss to make the answer probability distribution from the new question as close as possible to the corresponding distribution from the original question. Results from experiments on two benchmark datasets show that XNLI models enhanced by the proposed framework outperform the original models in both full-shot and few-shot cross-lingual transfer settings.

label: acl
text: This paper addresses the problem of dialogue reasoning with contextualized commonsense inference. We curate CICERO, a dataset of dyadic conversations with five types of utterance-level reasoning-based inferences: cause, subsequent event, prerequisite, motivation, and emotional reaction. The dataset contains 53,105 of such inferences from 5,672 dialogues. We use this dataset to solve relevant generative and discriminative tasks: generation of cause and subsequent event; generation of prerequisite, motivation, and listener's emotional reaction; and selection of plausible alternatives. Our results ascertain the value of such dialogue-centric commonsense knowledge datasets. It is our hope that CICERO will open new research avenues into commonsense-based dialogue reasoning.

label: acl
text: The present study tackles the challenge of dialogue reasoning with contextualized commonsense inference. To address this issue, we have curated CICERO, a dataset of dyadic conversations that includes five different types of utterance-level reasoning-based inferences: cause, subsequent event, prerequisite, motivation, and emotional reaction. The dataset comprises 53,105 inferences from 5,672 dialogues. We evaluate the dataset by conducting relevant generative and discriminative tasks, including the generation of cause and subsequent events, the generation of prerequisite, motivation, and listener's emotional reaction, and the selection of plausible alternatives. Our results demonstrate the significance of such dialogue-centric commonsense knowledge datasets and we hope that CICERO will pave the way for further research in commonsense-based dialogue reasoning.

label: emnlp
text: We introduce a novel multimodal machine translation model that utilizes parallel visual and textual information. Our model jointly optimizes the learning of a shared visual-language embedding and a translator. The model leverages a visual attention grounding mechanism that links the visual semantics with the corresponding textual semantics. Our approach achieves competitive state-of-the-art results on the Multi30K and the Ambiguous COCO datasets. We also collected a new multilingual multimodal product description dataset to simulate a real-world international online shopping scenario. On this dataset, our visual attention grounding model outperforms other methods by a large margin.

label: emnlp
text: Introducing a cutting-edge multimodal machine translation model, our approach utilizes parallel visual and textual information to jointly optimize the learning of a shared visual-language embedding and a translator. Our model features a visual attention grounding mechanism, linking visual semantics to the corresponding textual semantics for improved accuracy. Our results are competitive with state-of-the-art performance on the Multi30K and Ambiguous COCO datasets. To further test the real-world application of our model, we created a new multilingual multimodal product description dataset simulating an international online shopping scenario. Our visual attention grounding model outperforms other methods by a significant margin on this dataset.

label: acl
text: Pre-trained contextual representations have led to dramatic performance improvements on a range of downstream tasks. Such performance improvements have motivated researchers to quantify and understand the linguistic information encoded in these representations. In general, researchers quantify the amount of linguistic information through probing, an endeavor which consists of training a supervised model to predict a linguistic property directly from the contextual representations. Unfortunately, this definition of probing has been subject to extensive criticism in the literature, and has been observed to lead to paradoxical and counter-intuitive results. In the theoretical portion of this paper, we take the position that the goal of probing ought to be measuring the amount of inductive bias that the representations encode on a specific task. We further describe a Bayesian framework that operationalizes this goal and allows us to quantify the representations' inductive bias. In the empirical portion of the paper, we apply our framework to a variety of NLP tasks. Our results suggest that our proposed framework alleviates many previous problems found in probing. Moreover, we are able to offer concrete evidence that—for some tasks—fastText can offer a better inductive bias than BERT.

label: acl
text: Pre-trained contextual representations have resulted in significant performance enhancements across various downstream tasks, inspiring researchers to quantify and comprehend the linguistic information they encode. To do this, researchers typically use a method called probing, which involves training a supervised model to predict linguistic properties directly from the contextual representations. However, this approach has faced criticism and has been known to produce paradoxical and unexpected results. In this paper, we argue that the goal of probing should be to measure the inductive bias encoded in the representations for a specific task. We present a Bayesian framework that operationalizes this goal and enables us to quantify the inductive bias of the representations. In the empirical section, we apply our framework to various NLP tasks and find that our proposed framework addresses many of the previous issues found in probing. Additionally, our results provide concrete evidence that, for some tasks, fastText may offer a better inductive bias than BERT.

label: naacl
text: Borrowing ideas from Production functions in micro-economics, in this paper we introduce a framework to systematically evaluate the performance and cost trade-offs between machine-translated and manually-created labelled data for task-specific fine-tuning of massively multilingual language models. We illustrate the effectiveness of our framework through a case-study on the TyDIQA-GoldP dataset. One of the interesting conclusion of the study is that if the cost of machine translation is greater than zero, the optimal performance at least cost is always achieved with at least some or only manually-created data. To our knowledge, this is the first attempt towards extending the concept of production functions to study data collection strategies for training multilingual models, and can serve as a valuable tool for other similar cost vs data trade-offs in NLP.

label: naacl
text: In this paper, we present a framework that leverages the concepts of production functions in micro-economics to systematically evaluate the trade-off between performance and cost for machine-translated and manually-created labeled data in fine-tuning massively multilingual language models. Our framework is demonstrated through a case-study on the TyDIQA-GoldP dataset, which reveals that, when the cost of machine translation is greater than zero, the optimal performance at the least cost is achieved with at least some or only manually-created data. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to apply production functions to the study of data collection strategies for training multilingual models and can serve as a useful tool for similar cost vs. data trade-offs in NLP.

label: acl
text: Existing reference-free metrics have obvious limitations for evaluating controlled text generation models. Unsupervised metrics can only provide a task-agnostic evaluation result which correlates weakly with human judgments, whereas supervised ones may overfit task-specific data with poor generalization ability to other datasets. In this paper, we propose an unsupervised reference-free metric called CTRLEval, which evaluates controlled text generation from different aspects by formulating each aspect into multiple text infilling tasks. On top of these tasks, the metric assembles the generation probabilities from a pre-trained language model without any model training. Experimental results show that our metric has higher correlations with human judgments than other baselines, while obtaining better generalization of evaluating generated texts from different models and with different qualities.

label: acl
text: In this paper, we propose CTRLEval, an unsupervised reference-free metric for evaluating controlled text generation models. Existing metrics have limitations, with unsupervised metrics providing weak correlations with human judgments and supervised metrics overfitting to task-specific data with poor generalization ability. CTRLEval evaluates controlled text generation from multiple aspects by formulating each aspect into text infilling tasks. The metric then uses the generation probabilities from a pre-trained language model without any additional training. Our results show that CTRLEval has a stronger correlation with human judgments than other baselines and better generalization for evaluating generated texts from different models and of varying quality.

label: naacl
text: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated human-level performance on a vast spectrum of natural language tasks. However, it is largely unexplored whether they can better internalize knowledge from a structured data, such as a knowledge graph, or from text. In this work, we propose a method to infuse structured knowledge into LLMs, by directly training T5 models on factual triples of knowledge graphs (KGs). We show that models pre-trained on Wikidata KG with our method outperform the T5 baselines on FreebaseQA and WikiHop, as well as the Wikidata-answerable subset of TriviaQA and NaturalQuestions. The models pre-trained on factual triples compare competitively with the ones on natural language sentences that contain the same knowledge. Trained on a smaller size KG, WikiMovies, we saw 3x improvement of exact match score on MetaQA task. The proposed method has an advantage that no alignment between the knowledge graph and text corpus is required in curating training data. This makes our method particularly useful when working with industry-scale knowledge graphs.

label: naacl
text: Large language models (LLMs) have been shown to perform at a human level on a wide range of natural language tasks. However, it remains largely unknown if they can effectively internalize knowledge from structured data such as a knowledge graph or text. In this study, we propose a method for infusing structured knowledge into LLMs by directly training T5 models on factual triples from knowledge graphs (KGs). Our results show that models pre-trained on the Wikidata KG using our method outperform T5 baselines on FreebaseQA and WikiHop, as well as the Wikidata-answerable subset of TriviaQA and NaturalQuestions. The models pre-trained on factual triples are also competitive with models trained on natural language sentences containing the same knowledge. When trained on a smaller KG, WikiMovies, we saw a 3x improvement in exact match scores on the MetaQA task. Our method has the advantage of not requiring alignment between the knowledge graph and text corpus in curating training data, making it particularly useful for industry-scale knowledge graphs.
