text: Collecting microblogs that express opinions about the same topics within a specific timeframe is useful for various tasks and practitioners. However, evaluating the quality of these thematic clusters remains a significant challenge. To address this, we created a corpus of microblog clusters from three different domains and time frames and defined the task of evaluating thematic coherence. Our annotation guidelines, along with human annotations by journalist experts, provide a basis for evaluating the coherence of these clusters. We then compared the effectiveness of different automated evaluation metrics, including surface-level metrics, topic model coherence metrics, and text generation metrics (TGMs). While surface-level metrics performed well, outperforming topic coherence metrics, they were not as consistent as TGMs. Our findings indicate that TGMs are the most reliable metric for capturing thematic coherence in microblog clusters, as they are less sensitive to the impact of time windows.

label: emnlp
text: There has always been criticism for using C-C-C-gram based similarity metrics, such as BLEU, NIST, etc, for evaluating the performance of NLG systems. However, these metrics continue to remain popular and are recently being used for evaluating the performance of systems which automatically generate questions from documents, knowledge graphs, images, etc. Given the rising interest in such automatic question generation (AQG) systems, it is important to objectively examine whether these metrics are suitable for this task. In particular, it is important to verify whether such metrics used for evaluating AQG systems focus on answerability of the generated question by preferring questions which contain all relevant information such as question type (Wh-types), entities, relations, etc. In this work, we show that current automatic evaluation metrics based on D-D-D-gram similarity do not always correlate well with human judgments about answerability of a question. To alleviate this problem and as a first step towards better evaluation metrics for AQG, we introduce a scoring function to capture answerability and show that when this scoring function is integrated with existing metrics, they correlate significantly better with human judgments. The scripts and data developed as a part of this work are made publicly available.

label: emnlp
text: There has been criticism of using C-C-C-gram-based similarity metrics, such as BLEU, NIST, etc., for evaluating the performance of natural language generation (NLG) systems. Despite this criticism, these metrics continue to be used, particularly for evaluating systems that automatically generate questions from documents, knowledge graphs, images, etc. Given the growing interest in automatic question generation (AQG) systems, it is crucial to objectively assess the suitability of these metrics. In particular, it is important to determine if these metrics accurately evaluate the answerability of the generated questions by considering factors such as question type (Wh-types), entities, relations, etc. This work shows that current automatic evaluation metrics based on D-D-D-gram similarity do not always align with human judgments about answerability. To address this issue and improve AQG evaluation metrics, we introduce a scoring function to capture answerability and demonstrate that integrating this function with existing metrics significantly improves their correlation with human judgments. The scripts and data developed as part of this work are available to the public.

label: emnlp
text: When a reader is first introduced to an entity, its referring expression must describe the entity. For entities that are widely known, a single word or phrase often suffices. This paper presents the first study of how expressions that refer to the same entity develop over time. We track thousands of person and organization entities over 20 years of New York Times (NYT). As entities move from hearer-new (first introduction to the NYT audience) to hearer-old (common knowledge) status, we show empirically that the referring expressions along this trajectory depend on the type of the entity, and exhibit linguistic properties related to becoming common knowledge (e.g., shorter length, less use of appositives, more definiteness). These properties can also be used to build a model to predict how long it will take for an entity to reach hearer-old status. Our results reach 10-30% absolute improvement over a majority-class baseline.

label: emnlp
text: When a reader is first introduced to an entity, its referring expression must be descriptive. For entities that are well-known, a simple word or phrase is usually sufficient. This study is the first to examine how referring expressions change over time for the same entity. By tracking thousands of person and organization entities over a 20-year period in The New York Times, we demonstrate that the development of referring expressions depends on the type of entity and exhibits linguistic properties related to becoming common knowledge, such as shorter length, reduced use of appositives, and increased definiteness. Our findings can be used to create a model that predicts how long it will take for an entity to reach a state of common knowledge. Our results show an improvement of 10-30% compared to a majority-class baseline.

label: acl
text: Modern neural machine translation (NMT) models have achieved competitive performance in standard benchmarks such as WMT. However, there still exist significant issues such as robustness, domain generalization, etc. In this paper, we study NMT models from the perspective of compositional generalization by building a benchmark dataset, CoGnition, consisting of 216k clean and consistent sentence pairs. We quantitatively analyze effects of various factors using compound translation error rate, then demonstrate that the NMT model fails badly on compositional generalization, although it performs remarkably well under traditional metrics.

label: acl
text: Modern NMT models have achieved impressive results in standard benchmarks such as WMT, but there are still significant challenges, such as robustness and domain generalization. This paper explores NMT models from the standpoint of compositional generalization by creating a benchmark dataset, CoGnition, which consists of 216k clean and consistent sentence pairs. We use the compound translation error rate to quantify the impact of various factors and show that, despite performing well under traditional metrics, NMT models struggle with compositional generalization.

label: coling
text: When a natural language generation (NLG) component is implemented in a real-world task-oriented dialogue system, it is necessary to generate not only natural utterances as learned on training data but also utterances adapted to the dialogue environment (e.g., noise from environmental sounds) and the user (e.g., users with low levels of understanding ability). Inspired by recent advances in reinforcement learning (RL) for language generation tasks, we propose ANTOR, a method for Adaptive Natural language generation for Task-Oriented dialogue via Reinforcement learning. In ANTOR, a natural language understanding (NLU) module, which corresponds to the user's understanding of system utterances, is incorporated into the objective function of RL. If the NLG's intentions are correctly conveyed to the NLU, which understands a system's utterances, the NLG is given a positive reward. We conducted experiments on the MultiWOZ dataset, and we confirmed that ANTOR could generate adaptive utterances against speech recognition errors and the different vocabulary levels of users.

label: coling
text: When implementing a natural language generation (NLG) component in a real-world task-oriented dialogue system, it is crucial to generate not only natural utterances based on training data, but also to adapt to the dialogue environment and the user. To achieve this, we propose ANTOR – a reinforcement learning (RL) based method for adaptive natural language generation in task-oriented dialogue. ANTOR incorporates a natural language understanding (NLU) module into the objective function of RL, so that the NLG's intentions are correctly conveyed to the NLU. If the NLU understands the system's utterances, the NLG is rewarded positively. Our experiments on the MultiWOZ dataset show that ANTOR can generate adaptive utterances that are robust against speech recognition errors and the varying vocabulary levels of users.

label: emnlp
text: State-of-the-art networks that model relations between two pieces of text often use complex architectures and attention. In this paper, instead of focusing on architecture engineering, we take advantage of small amounts of labelled data that model semantic phenomena in text to encode matching features directly in the word representations. This greatly boosts the accuracy of our reference network, while keeping the model simple and fast to train. Our approach also beats a tree kernel model that uses similar input encodings, and neural models which use advanced attention and compare-aggregate mechanisms.

label: emnlp
text: The latest state-of-the-art networks that model the relationship between two pieces of text often employ complex architectures and attention mechanisms. In contrast, this paper focuses on utilizing small amounts of labeled data that model semantic phenomena in text to directly encode matching features into the word representations. This significantly improves the accuracy of our reference network while maintaining a simple and efficient training process. Our approach outperforms both a tree kernel model that uses similar input encodings and neural models that utilize advanced attention and compare-aggregate techniques.

label: acl
text: Knowledge probing is crucial for understanding the knowledge transfer mechanism behind the pre-trained language models (PLMs). Despite the growing progress of probing knowledge for PLMs in the general domain, specialised areas such as the biomedical domain are vastly under-explored. To facilitate this, we release a well-curated biomedical knowledge probing benchmark, MedLAMA, constructed based on the Unified Medical Language System (UMLS) Metathesaurus. We test a wide spectrum of state-of-the-art PLMs and probing approaches on our benchmark, reaching at most 3% of acc@10. While highlighting various sources of domain-specific challenges that amount to this underwhelming performance, we illustrate that the underlying PLMs have a higher potential for probing tasks. To achieve this, we propose Contrastive-Probe, a novel self-supervised contrastive probing approach, that adjusts the underlying PLMs without using any probing data. While Contrastive-Probe pushes the acc@10 to 28%, the performance gap still remains notable. Our human expert evaluation suggests that the probing performance of our Contrastive-Probe is still under-estimated as UMLS still does not include the full spectrum of factual knowledge. We hope MedLAMA and Contrastive-Probe facilitate further developments of more suited probing techniques for this domain. Our code and dataset are publicly available at https://github.com/cambridgeltl/medlama.

label: acl
text: Probing the knowledge of pre-trained language models (PLMs) is essential to understanding their knowledge transfer mechanism. Despite advances in probing PLMs in the general domain, specialized areas such as the biomedical domain have been largely neglected. To address this, we present MedLAMA, a well-curated biomedical knowledge probing benchmark, constructed using the Unified Medical Language System (UMLS) Metathesaurus. We evaluate a range of state-of-the-art PLMs and probing methods on our benchmark, with a maximum accuracy of 3% at 10. We highlight the challenges specific to the biomedical domain that contribute to this performance, but also demonstrate that PLMs have the potential for improved probing results. To achieve this, we introduce Contrastive-Probe, a novel self-supervised contrastive probing method that adjusts PLMs without using any probing data. Although Contrastive-Probe increases accuracy to 28%, the performance gap remains significant. Our human expert evaluation suggests that the probing performance of Contrastive-Probe is still underestimated, as the UMLS does not cover the full range of factual knowledge. We hope that MedLAMA and Contrastive-Probe will drive further development of more effective probing techniques for the biomedical domain. Our code and dataset are publicly available at https://github.com/cambridgeltl/medlama.

label: coling
text: Existing fake news detection methods aim to classify a piece of news as true or false and provide veracity explanations, achieving remarkable performances. However, they often tailor automated solutions on manual fact-checked reports, suffering from limited news coverage and debunking delays. When a piece of news has not yet been fact-checked or debunked, certain amounts of relevant raw reports are usually disseminated on various media outlets, containing the wisdom of crowds to verify the news claim and explain its verdict. In this paper, we propose a novel Coarse-to-fine Cascaded Evidence-Distillation (CofCED) neural network for explainable fake news detection based on such raw reports, alleviating the dependency on fact-checked ones. Specifically, we first utilize a hierarchical encoder for web text representation, and then develop two cascaded selectors to select the most explainable sentences for verdicts on top of the selected top-K reports in a coarse-to-fine manner. Besides, we construct two explainable fake news datasets, which is publicly available. Experimental results demonstrate that our model significantly outperforms state-of-the-art detection baselines and generates high-quality explanations from diverse evaluation perspectives.

label: coling
text: Current methods for detecting fake news aim to classify news as true or false and provide veracity explanations, with impressive results. However, these methods often rely on manually fact-checked reports, which can lead to limited news coverage and slow debunking times. When a piece of news hasn't been fact-checked, raw reports from various media outlets are often disseminated, containing the collective wisdom of the crowd to verify the news claim and explain its verdict. In this paper, we propose a novel Coarse-to-fine Cascaded Evidence-Distillation (CofCED) neural network for explainable fake news detection based on raw reports, reducing the dependence on fact-checked reports. Our model uses a hierarchical encoder for web text representation and two cascaded selectors to select the most explainable sentences for verdicts, using a coarse-to-fine approach. We also publicly release two explainable fake news datasets. Our results show that our model outperforms existing detection methods and generates high-quality explanations from various evaluation perspectives.

label: emnlp
text: Neural NLP systems achieve high scores in the presence of sizable training dataset. Lack of such datasets leads to poor system performances in the case low-resource languages. We present two simple text augmentation techniques using dependency trees, inspired from image processing. We “crop” sentences by removing dependency links, and we “rotate” sentences by moving the tree fragments around the root. We apply these techniques to augment the training sets of low-resource languages in Universal Dependencies project. We implement a character-level sequence tagging model and evaluate the augmented datasets on part-of-speech tagging task. We show that crop and rotate provides improvements over the models trained with non-augmented data for majority of the languages, especially for languages with rich case marking systems.

label: emnlp
text: Neural NLP systems perform well when they are trained on a large dataset. However, poor performance is observed when they are used on low-resource languages that lack such datasets. To overcome this limitation, we propose two text augmentation techniques based on dependency trees. These techniques, called "cropping" and "rotating," involve removing and rearranging tree fragments, respectively. We apply these techniques to augment the training sets of low-resource languages in the Universal Dependencies project. We then evaluate the effectiveness of these techniques by implementing a character-level sequence tagging model and testing it on part-of-speech tagging tasks. The results show that the crop and rotate techniques significantly improve the performance of the models trained on the augmented data, especially for languages with rich case marking systems.

label: coling
text: Modeling U.S. Congressional legislation and roll-call votes has received significant attention in previous literature, and while legislators across 50 state governments and D.C. propose over 100,000 bills each year, enacting over 30% of them on average, state level analysis has received relatively less attention due in part to the difficulty in obtaining the necessary data. Since each state legislature is guided by their own procedures, politics and issues, however, it is difficult to qualitatively asses the factors that affect the likelihood of a legislative initiative succeeding. We present several methods for modeling the likelihood of a bill receiving floor action across all 50 states and D.C. We utilize the lexical content of over 1 million bills, along with contextual legislature and legislator derived features to build our predictive models, allowing a comparison of what factors are important to the lawmaking process. Furthermore, we show that these signals hold complementary predictive power, together achieving an average improvement in accuracy of 18% over state specific baselines.

label: coling
text: Modeling the legislation and roll-call votes of the U.S. Congressional has received considerable attention in previous studies. Despite the fact that legislators across the 50 states and D.C. propose over 100,000 bills each year, with over 30% of them enacted on average, analysis at the state level has received relatively less attention, partly due to the difficulty in obtaining the necessary data. As each state legislature operates differently, with its own procedures, politics, and issues, it is challenging to assess the factors that influence the success of legislative initiatives. This study presents several methods for predicting the likelihood of a bill receiving floor action across all 50 states and D.C. Using the lexical content of over 1 million bills, along with contextual information about the legislature and legislators, we build predictive models to compare the factors that are crucial to the lawmaking process. Our results demonstrate that these signals have complementary predictive power, leading to an average improvement in accuracy of 18% over state-specific baselines.

label: acl
text: In this digital age, online users expect personalized content. To cater to diverse group of audiences across online platforms it is necessary to generate multiple variants of same content with differing degree of characteristics (sentiment, style, formality, etc.). Though text-style transfer is a well explored related area, it focuses on flipping the style attribute polarity instead of regulating a fine-grained attribute transfer. In this paper we propose a hierarchical architecture for finer control over the at- tribute, preserving content using attribute dis- entanglement. We demonstrate the effective- ness of the generative process for two different attributes with varied complexity, namely sentiment and formality. With extensive experiments and human evaluation on five real-world datasets, we show that the framework can generate natural looking sentences with finer degree of control of intensity of a given attribute.

label: acl
text: In this digital era, online users expect customized content. To accommodate a diverse range of audiences across online platforms, it is essential to generate multiple versions of the same content with varying degrees of characteristics, such as sentiment, style, formality, etc. Although text-style transfer is a well-studied area, it only focuses on flipping the style attribute's polarity, rather than regulating fine-grained attribute transfer. This paper proposes a hierarchical architecture for greater control over attributes while preserving content through attribute disentanglement. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the generative process for two attributes with varying complexity: sentiment and formality. With comprehensive experiments and human evaluations on five real-world datasets, we show that our framework can generate natural-looking sentences with finer control over the intensity of a given attribute.

label: coling
text: In this study, we propose a morpheme-based scheme for Korean dependency parsing and adopt the proposed scheme to Universal Dependencies. We present the linguistic rationale that illustrates the motivation and the necessity of adopting the morpheme-based format, and develop scripts that convert between the original format used by Universal Dependencies and the proposed morpheme-based format automatically. The effectiveness of the proposed format for Korean dependency parsing is then testified by both statistical and neural models, including UDPipe and Stanza, with our carefully constructed morpheme-based word embedding for Korean. morphUD outperforms parsing results for all Korean UD treebanks, and we also present detailed error analysis.

label: coling
text: In this study, we introduce a morpheme-based scheme for Korean dependency parsing and apply it to Universal Dependencies. We provide a linguistic explanation for the motivation and necessity of using the morpheme-based format and create scripts that automatically convert between the original Universal Dependencies format and the proposed morpheme-based format. The effectiveness of the proposed format is demonstrated through statistical and neural models, including UDPipe and Stanza, using our carefully crafted Korean morpheme-based word embedding. Our results show that morphUD outperforms all Korean UD treebanks, and we present a thorough error analysis.

label: naacl
text: There has been a recent wave of work assessing the fairness of machine learning models in general, and more specifically, on natural language processing (NLP) models built using machine learning techniques. While much work has highlighted biases embedded in state-of-the-art language models, and more recent efforts have focused on how to debias, research assessing the fairness and performance of biased/debiased models on downstream prediction tasks has been limited. Moreover, most prior work has emphasized bias along a single dimension such as gender or race. In this work, we benchmark multiple NLP models with regards to their fairness and predictive performance across a variety of NLP tasks. In particular, we assess intersectional bias - fairness across multiple demographic dimensions. The results show that while current debiasing strategies fare well in terms of the fairness-accuracy trade-off (generally preserving predictive power in debiased models), they are unable to effectively alleviate bias in downstream tasks. Furthermore, this bias is often amplified across dimensions (i.e., intersections). We conclude by highlighting possible causes and making recommendations for future NLP debiasing research.

label: naacl
text: There has been a recent surge of studies evaluating the fairness of machine learning models, particularly in the area of natural language processing (NLP) models. Although much attention has been given to the biases present in state-of-the-art language models and efforts have been made to debias them, limited research has been done to assess the fairness and performance of both biased and debiased models in downstream prediction tasks. Most previous studies have only focused on one dimension of bias, such as gender or race. In this study, we compare multiple NLP models in terms of their fairness and predictive performance across various NLP tasks, with a particular emphasis on intersectional bias, which refers to fairness across multiple demographic dimensions. Our findings indicate that while current debiasing strategies preserve predictive power, they are unable to effectively eliminate bias in downstream tasks. Moreover, this bias is often amplified across multiple dimensions. Finally, we discuss potential causes and offer recommendations for future NLP debiasing research.

label: coling
text: Access to higher education is critical for minority populations and emergent bilingual students. However, the language used by higher education institutions to communicate with prospective students is often too complex; concretely, many institutions in the US publish admissions application instructions far above the average reading level of a typical high school graduate, often near the 13th or 14th grade level. This leads to an unnecessary barrier between students and access to higher education. This work aims to tackle this challenge via text simplification. We present PSAT (Professionally Simplified Admissions Texts), a dataset with 112 admissions instructions randomly selected from higher education institutions across the US. These texts are then professionally simplified, and verified and accepted by subject-matter experts who are full-time employees in admissions offices at various institutions. Additionally, PSAT comes with manual alignments of 1,883 original-simplified sentence pairs. The result is a first-of-its-kind corpus for the evaluation and fine-tuning of text simplification systems in a high-stakes genre distinct from existing simplification resources.

label: coling
text: Access to higher education is essential for minority populations and emergent bilingual students, but the language used by higher education institutions in communication with prospective students is often too complex. In the US, many institutions publish admissions application instructions at a reading level far above that of a typical high school graduate, often near the 13th or 14th grade level, creating an unnecessary barrier to education. To address this challenge, this work introduces PSAT (Professionally Simplified Admissions Texts), a dataset consisting of 112 admissions instructions from various higher education institutions in the US, which have been professionally simplified and verified by subject-matter experts who work in admissions offices. The dataset also includes 1,883 original-simplified sentence pairs, making it a unique resource for evaluating and improving text simplification systems in a high-stakes genre that is different from existing simplification resources.

label: acl
text: Machine Translation Quality Estimation (QE) aims to build predictive models to assess the quality of machine-generated translations in the absence of reference translations. While state-of-the-art QE models have been shown to achieve good results, they over-rely on features that do not have a causal impact on the quality of a translation. In particular, there appears to be a partial input bias, i.e., a tendency to assign high-quality scores to translations that are fluent and grammatically correct, even though they do not preserve the meaning of the source. We analyse the partial input bias in further detail and evaluate four approaches to use auxiliary tasks for bias mitigation. Two approaches use additional data to inform and support the main task, while the other two are adversarial, actively discouraging the model from learning the bias. We compare the methods with respect to their ability to reduce the partial input bias while maintaining the overall performance. We find that training a multitask architecture with an auxiliary binary classification task that utilises additional augmented data best achieves the desired effects and generalises well to different languages and quality metrics.

label: acl
text: The goal of Machine Translation Quality Estimation (QE) is to create predictive models that can evaluate the quality of machine-generated translations when there are no reference translations available. Despite the fact that current state-of-the-art QE models have been proven to produce good results, they tend to heavily rely on features that have no direct impact on the quality of a translation. Specifically, there is a tendency to assign high-quality scores to translations that are grammatically correct and fluent, even if they don't accurately convey the meaning of the source text. In this study, we delve deeper into this partial input bias and evaluate four methods for mitigating it. Two of these methods use additional data to support the main task, while the other two are adversarial and actively discourage the model from learning the bias. We compare the methods' ability to reduce the partial input bias while still maintaining overall performance. Our results show that using a multitask architecture with an auxiliary binary classification task, which utilizes augmented data, is the best approach for achieving the desired effects and generalizing well to different languages and quality metrics.

label: naacl
text: Event Detection (ED) is the task of identifying and classifying trigger words of event mentions in text. Despite considerable research efforts in recent years for English text, the task of ED in other languages has been significantly less explored. Switching to non-English languages, important research questions for ED include how well existing ED models perform on different languages, how challenging ED is in other languages, and how well ED knowledge and annotation can be transferred across languages. To answer those questions, it is crucial to obtain multilingual ED datasets that provide consistent event annotation for multiple languages. There exist some multilingual ED datasets; however, they tend to cover a handful of languages and mainly focus on popular ones. Many languages are not covered in existing multilingual ED datasets. In addition, the current datasets are often small and not accessible to the public. To overcome those shortcomings, we introduce a new large-scale multilingual dataset for ED (called MINION) that consistently annotates events for 8 different languages; 5 of them have not been supported by existing multilingual datasets. We also perform extensive experiments and analysis to demonstrate the challenges and transferability of ED across languages in MINION that in all call for more research effort in this area. We will release the dataset to promote future research on multilingual ED.

label: naacl
text: Event Detection (ED) refers to the process of identifying and categorizing trigger words of event mentions in text. Despite significant research efforts in recent years for English text, the task of ED in other languages remains largely unexplored. When considering non-English languages, important research questions include: the performance of existing ED models on different languages, the difficulty level of ED in other languages, and the transferability of ED knowledge and annotations across languages. To answer these questions, it is essential to have multilingual ED datasets that provide consistent event annotations in multiple languages. Although there are some multilingual ED datasets available, they tend to be limited in scope, covering only a few popular languages. Furthermore, these datasets are often small and not publicly accessible. To address these issues, we have created a new, large-scale multilingual ED dataset (MINION), which provides consistent event annotations for 8 different languages, including 5 languages that are not covered by existing datasets. Through extensive experiments and analysis, we demonstrate the challenges and transferability of ED across languages in MINION and highlight the need for further research in this area. We will make the dataset publicly available to encourage future research on multilingual ED.

label: coling
text: Dataset bias in stance detection tasks allows models to achieve superior performance without using targets. Most existing debiasing methods are task-agnostic, which fail to utilize task knowledge to better discriminate between genuine and bias features. Motivated by how humans tackle stance detection tasks, we propose to incorporate the stance reasoning process as task knowledge to assist in learning genuine features and reducing reliance on bias features. The full stance reasoning process usually involves identifying the span of the mentioned target and corresponding opinion expressions, such fine-grained annotations are hard and expensive to obtain. To alleviate this, we simplify the stance reasoning process to relax the granularity of annotations from token-level to sentence-level, where labels for sub-tasks can be easily inferred from existing resources. We further implement those sub-tasks by maximizing mutual information between the texts and the opinioned targets. To evaluate whether stance detection models truly understand the task from various aspects, we collect and construct a series of new test sets. Our proposed model achieves better performance than previous task-agnostic debiasing methods on most of those new test sets while maintaining comparable performances to existing stance detection models.

label: coling
text: Dataset bias in stance detection tasks allows models to achieve superior performance without actually using the target. Most existing debiasing methods are not specific to the task and therefore, they are unable to effectively discriminate between genuine and biased features. Inspired by the human approach to stance detection, we propose incorporating the stance reasoning process as task knowledge to help learn genuine features and reduce reliance on biased features. The full stance reasoning process typically involves identifying the target span and opinion expressions, but obtaining fine-grained annotations for this is difficult and expensive. To overcome this, we simplify the stance reasoning process by reducing the granularity of annotations from token-level to sentence-level, making it easier to infer labels for sub-tasks from existing resources. We implement these sub-tasks by maximizing the mutual information between the text and the opinioned targets. To ensure that our model truly understands the task from various perspectives, we have created a series of new test sets. Our proposed model outperforms previous task-agnostic debiasing methods on most of these new test sets, while maintaining comparable performance to existing stance detection models.

label: acl
text: Multimodal machine translation (MMT) aims to improve neural machine translation (NMT) with additional visual information, but most existing MMT methods require paired input of source sentence and image, which makes them suffer from shortage of sentence-image pairs. In this paper, we propose a phrase-level retrieval-based method for MMT to get visual information for the source input from existing sentence-image data sets so that MMT can break the limitation of paired sentence-image input. Our method performs retrieval at the phrase level and hence learns visual information from pairs of source phrase and grounded region, which can mitigate data sparsity. Furthermore, our method employs the conditional variational auto-encoder to learn visual representations which can filter redundant visual information and only retain visual information related to the phrase. Experiments show that the proposed method significantly outperforms strong baselines on multiple MMT datasets, especially when the textual context is limited.

label: acl
text: Multimodal machine translation (MMT) aims to enhance neural machine translation (NMT) by incorporating additional visual information. However, most existing MMT methods require a paired source sentence and image input, which limits their effectiveness due to a shortage of sentence-image pairs. To overcome this limitation, we propose a phrase-level retrieval-based MMT method that retrieves visual information from existing sentence-image datasets for the source input. Our method performs retrieval at the phrase level and learns visual information from source phrase-grounded region pairs, reducing data sparsity. Additionally, our method employs a conditional variational auto-encoder to learn visual representations that filter redundant information and retain only the information related to the source phrase. Our experiments show that our proposed method outperforms strong baselines on multiple MMT datasets, particularly when the textual context is limited.

label: coling
text: Capturing semantic relations between sentences, such as entailment, is a long-standing challenge for computational semantics. Logic-based models analyse entailment in terms of possible worlds (interpretations, or situations) where a premise P entails a hypothesis H iff in all worlds where P is true, H is also true. Statistical models view this relationship probabilistically, addressing it in terms of whether a human would likely infer H from P. In this paper, we wish to bridge these two perspectives, by arguing for a visually-grounded version of the Textual Entailment task. Specifically, we ask whether models can perform better if, in addition to P and H, there is also an image (corresponding to the relevant “world” or “situation”). We use a multimodal version of the SNLI dataset (Bowman et al., 2015) and we compare “blind” and visually-augmented models of textual entailment. We show that visual information is beneficial, but we also conduct an in-depth error analysis that reveals that current multimodal models are not performing “grounding” in an optimal fashion.

label: coling
text: The challenge of capturing semantic relations between sentences, such as entailment, has been a long-standing issue in computational semantics. Logic-based models analyze entailment in terms of possible worlds, where a premise (P) entails a hypothesis (H) if H is true in all worlds where P is true. On the other hand, statistical models approach this relationship probabilistically, based on the likelihood of a human inferring H from P. In this paper, we aim to bridge these two perspectives by proposing a visually-grounded version of the Textual Entailment task. We test whether models can perform better when an image corresponding to the relevant "world" or "situation" is added to P and H. We use the multimodal version of the SNLI dataset and compare "blind" and visually-augmented models of textual entailment. Our results show that visual information is beneficial, but a thorough error analysis reveals that current multimodal models are not optimally performing "grounding.

label: emnlp
text: Modern automated dialog systems require complex dialog managers able to deal with user intent triggered by high-level semantic questions. In this paper, we propose a model for automatically clustering questions into user intents to help the design tasks. Since questions are short texts, uncovering their semantics to group them together can be very challenging. We approach the problem by using powerful semantic classifiers from question duplicate/matching research along with a novel idea of supervised clustering methods based on structured output. We test our approach on two intent clustering corpora, showing an impressive improvement over previous methods for two languages/domains.

label: emnlp
text: Modern automated dialog systems require advanced dialog managers that can effectively handle user intent triggered by high-level semantic questions. In this paper, we present a model for automatically grouping questions into user intents to aid in the design process. As questions are short texts, determining their semantic meaning and grouping them together can be a difficult task. We tackle this challenge by utilizing state-of-the-art semantic classifiers from question duplicate/matching research and incorporating a novel approach of supervised clustering methods based on structured output. Our approach is tested on two intent clustering corpora, resulting in a significant improvement over previous methods for two languages/domains.

label: acl
text: Event forecasting is a challenging, yet important task, as humans seek to constantly plan for the future. Existing automated forecasting studies rely mostly on structured data, such as time-series or event-based knowledge graphs, to help predict future events. In this work, we aim to formulate a task, construct a dataset, and provide benchmarks for developing methods for event forecasting with large volumes of unstructured text data. To simulate the forecasting scenario on temporal news documents, we formulate the problem as a restricted-domain, multiple-choice, question-answering (QA) task. Unlike existing QA tasks, our task limits accessible information, and thus a model has to make a forecasting judgement. To showcase the usefulness of this task formulation, we introduce ForecastQA, a question-answering dataset consisting of 10,392 event forecasting questions, which have been collected and verified via crowdsourcing efforts. We present our experiments on ForecastQA using BERTbased models and find that our best model achieves 61.0% accuracy on the dataset, which still lags behind human performance by about 19%. We hope ForecastQA will support future research efforts in bridging this gap.

text: Event forecasting is a demanding yet crucial task as people strive to plan for the future. label: coling
text: A math word problem (MWP) is a coherent narrative which reflects the underlying logic of math equations. Successful MWP generation can automate the writing of mathematics questions. Previous methods mainly generate MWP text based on inflexible pre-defined templates. In this paper, we propose a neural model for generating MWP text from math equations. Firstly, we incorporate a matching model conditioned on the domain knowledge to retrieve a MWP instance which is most consistent with the ground-truth, where the domain is a latent variable extracted with a domain summarizer. Secondly, by constructing a Quantity Cell Graph (QCG) from the retrieved MWP instance and reasoning over it, we improve the model's comprehension of real-world scenarios and derive a domain-constrained instance sketch to guide the generation. Besides, the QCG also interacts with the equation encoder to enhance the alignment between math tokens (e.g., quantities and variables) and MWP text. Experiments and empirical analysis on educational MWP set show that our model achieves impressive performance in both automatic evaluation metrics and human evaluation metrics.

label: coling
text: A math word problem (MWP) is a coherent narrative that reflects the underlying logic of mathematical equations. Automating the writing of math questions can be achieved through successful MWP generation. Previous methods have mainly generated MWP text using rigid pre-defined templates. In this paper, we introduce a neural model for generating MWP text from mathematical equations. Our model incorporates a matching model that is conditioned on domain knowledge to retrieve the MWP instance that is most consistent with the ground-truth. The domain is extracted using a domain summarizer as a latent variable. By constructing a Quantity Cell Graph (QCG) from the retrieved MWP instance, we improve the model's understanding of real-world scenarios and derive a domain-constrained instance sketch to guide the generation.
